DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Inmates Riot At English Prison; 50 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-8 bgng `Hundreds of...' with 7 grafs to CLARIFY that most of prison appears to remain under control of inmates and that is is unclear how many prisoners still are rioting; pickup 9th graf pvs, `Scores of...'
DOC.TEXT: About 700 inmates rioted at a crowded 19th century prison Sunday, occupying rooftops, smashing windows and setting fires. At least 50 guards and inmates were injured, police said. Television newscasts carried unconfirmed reports that witnesses had seen up to 12 bodies. A police spokesman said inmates brought out of Strangeways Prison also reported deaths, but that police would not be able to confirm this until they reached the center of the complex. The Home Office said no hostages were being held, and police said talks with prisoners were under way. There was no clear indication of the cause of the rioting at the medium-security prison, built in the Victorian era and now one of the most crowded in Europe. Home Office spokesman Charles Keseru said prison officers regained control of one wing of the jail Sunday evening and found no seriously injured inmates. The office said 12 injured staff members and 25 inmates were taken to area hospitals. The rioters appeared to have the rest of the complex under control, however. Prisoners were surrendering to authorities and about 400 had given up late Sunday night, Keseru said. It was not clear how many still were participating in the riot or the circumstances of the prisoners who were not involved. The prison was built for 970 inmates but houses about 1,600. Hundreds of riot police surrounded the prison and a police helicopter hovered overhead as flames leaped 20 feet into the air from the prison gymnasium, where a fire burned out of control. Twenty-five firefighters under police protection battled the blaze as dense black smoke billowed above the building. Fires also were reported to have been set in three cells and a classroom as large groups of inmates rampaged inside. Those fires later were reported under control. Scores of police vans lined side streets around the prison, a mile from the Manchester city center in central England. The Home Office, responsible for prisons and law enforcement, said the perimeter of the prison was secure. An office statement said the uprising began in the prison chapel at 11 a.m., when 300 inmates attacked staff members. ``Those prisoners then gained access to the chapel roof and then broke into the living accommodation in the main prison. Other prisoners, including those on remand, joined in the disturbance and staff had to be withdrawn,'' the statement said. As many as 80 prisoners reportedly made their way on to the rooftops of the jail's F wing, the prison chapel and adjoining buildings. The windows of a central turret linking several wings were smashed as prisoners made their way to the roof. Once there, the prisoners tore roof tiles up and hurled them into the prison courtyard where there were believed to be groups of riot police and prison officers. The prison, built in 1868, has been criticized as cramped and inadequate because of the crowding. In response, Home Secretary David Waddington has announced plans to expand Strangeways. Judge Stephen Tumin, chief inspector of prisons, said in a report last week on Strangeways that one shower a week was the norm for the inmates and up to 400 men had no work assignments. He said the most dangerous men were locked up 22 hours a day. Last week, two prisoners at Strangeways climbed onto the roof in a protest, but the reason was not made public. The prison serves the local area; one-third of its inmates are awaiting trial and two-thirds have been sentenced, the Home Office said. Many of Britain's prisons date from Victorian times, and crowding has become a serious problem. One of the worst previous riots occurred in May 1989 at Risley Remand Center near Liverpool, when 54 inmates staged a rooftop demonstration and held off police for four days. The most famous riot in British penal history this century was at Dartmoor, the jail on the moors of Devon, where fighting over poor food and conditions in 1932 left 70 inmates and six guards injured.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Kaiser Employees Promise to Strike Monday
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of employees of local Kaiser Permanente hospitals and medical offices pledged to go on strike Monday after a weekend negotiating session failed to resolve a labor dispute, officials said Sunday. ``The union has issued a strike alert for one minute after midnight,'' said Janice Seib, a spokeswoman for Kaiser Permanente, the nation's oldest and largest health maintenance organization. The service employees union representing 11,000 hospital workers rejected Kaiser's three-year, $44-million contract, and a federally mediated session produced no new resolutions. The union includes licensed vocational nurses, clerks, house keepers and radiology technicians at seven of the Pasadena-based Kaiser Permanente Medical Centers and more than 40 satellite medical offices in Los Angeles and Orange counties. Kaiser will draw additional workers from other Kaiser facilities in San Bernardino, Riverside and San Diego counties that are unaffected by the strike called by clerical, technical and service employees, Seib said. ``We've already been reducing the number of patients in our hospitals from 40 to 60 percent,'' Seib said, adding officials have transferred some patients and postponed non-emergency surgeries and elective surgeries. A six-hour negotiating session with representatives from Service Employees International Union, Local 399 ended Saturday without an agreement, Seib said. ``The feeling is that we've presented the union with an extremely fair contract that guarantees they'll always be paid 4 percent higher than any other facility in the area,'' Seib said. The contract offer included a 5 percent to 6 percent raise in the first year and a 3 percent to 5 percent raise during the second and third year. The offer was approved by the union negotiating team on Thursday. The next day some 5,000 workers, less than half of the union membership, voted to rejected the contract by a more than two-to-one ratio, said Tom Ramsay, a union spokesman. Kaiser employees accepted a wage freeze three years ago and have stood by the company during its nine years of financial difficulty, Ramsay said. ``Now that Kaiser is back on their feet and prospering, employees expected some recognition and didn't get that, and they were very angry,'' Ramsay said. The hospitals affected by the labor dispute are located in Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City, Bellflower and Anaheim, said Seib.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Defector Surrenders in Slayings of Wife, Daughter
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet defector whose family joined him in the United States last year after a 9-year struggle allegedly shot and killed his wife and one daughter and wounded another daughter, police said Saturday. Valentin Bereza, 58, fled to Tennessee after the shootings Thursday night and surrendered Saturday morning to police in Nashville, police said. Nashville homicide detective Walter Keeler Jr. said Bereza was being held for Florida police on a fugitive warrant. Bereza is charged with the premeditated shooting deaths of his wife, Raisa Bereza, 53, and daughter Elena, 30, as well as the premeditated attempted murder of his second daughter, Tonya, 17, the sheriff's office in Lee County, Fla., said Saturday. Officers in North Fort Myers said Raisa and Elena Bereza died of gunshots to the head from a large-caliber handgun. Tonya Bereza was in fair condition in a hospital recovering from a gunshot to the face. According to Tonya, her father put on his best suit before announcing that he was ``unhappy with Elena's behavior,'' the statement said without elaboration. ``He gathered his family around the dinner table and told them, `I'm leaving and I'm going to kill you now,''' Lee County sheriff's spokesman Robert Graziano said. ``Then he pulled out a gun and started shooting.'' Tonya fled the house as Bereza went into another room to reload the gun, the sheriff's office said. Bereza, a civil engineer, defected from the Ukraine in the Soviet Union in July 1980 and had lived in Fort Myers for about three years, police said. With help from the U.S. government, Elena was able to emigrate last May and Raisa and Tonya followed in September. The State Department had been notified after the shooting Thursday in case he tried to leave the country.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Soldiers Attacked in Honduras
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with nine grafs to update with soldiers evacuated; Pickup 7th pvs, `Jessup said...'
DOC.TEXT: Snipers fired automatic weapons at a bus carrying 28 U.S. airmen along a mountain road Saturday, and seven soldiers were wounded, two seriously, U.S. officials said. An anonymous caller to the private radio network Radio America claimed responsibility on behalf of the leftist Morazano National Liberation Front. U.S. Embassy spokesman Terrence Kneebone said U.S. government personnel in Honduras had been on a precautionary alert ahead of the second anniversary this week of the burning of the U.S. consulate in Tegucigalpa to protest the extradition of an alleged drug kingpin. Three attackers fired on the bus six miles north of Tegucigalpa, the capital, said Maj. Bruce Jessup, a spokesman for U.S. troops based in the Central American nation. ``The Americans did not have time to return fire, although there were some security personnel on the bus,'' he said. Kneebone said that seven soldiers were wounded. He said one soldier shot in the head was in critical condition, and another wounded in the stomach was in ``delicate condition.'' Kneebone said the other five injured soldiers were out of danger. He said four of the five were being evacuated by air Saturday night to the U.S. Southern Command in Panama, ``where they have better treatment facilities at Gorgas Hospital than in Soto Cano.'' ``All five are out of danger. In fact, they walked out of the hospital after receiving first aid treatment earlier in the day,'' he said. Jessup said the servicemen are members of the U.S. Air Force, but he refused to identify them by unit or release the names of the injured. Asked how he knew there were three attackers, Jessup said the U.S. soldiers had seen them as they fled. A White House spokesman, Sean Walsh, said in Washington: ``We deplore any action against U.S. citizens. We'll be working closely with the Honduran government on the investigation.'' The Morazano Front, founded in 1979, is thought to be an arm of the Communist Party. The group takes its name from Gen. Francisco Morazan, a former president of Honduras. It claimed responsibility for the last major attack on U.S. forces in Honduras, on July 13, 1989, when a homemade bomb was thrown at nine U.S. Army military policemen in civilian clothes as they passed a discotheque in La Ceiba, 200 miles north of Tegucigalpa. Seven were injured. The group has also claimed reponsibility for a dynamite attack Aug. 27, 1987, on a restaurant in town of Comayagua, near Cano Soto Air Base. Six U.S. soldiers and six Honduras civilians were killed. The front also has claimed responsibility for six other similar attacks on U.S. targets during the past decade. At the time of the attack Saturday, the U.S. soldiers, who were dressed in civilian clothes, were returning from a brief period of rest at Tela, a northern resort, to a work site south of Tegucigalpa, U.S. officials said. A U.S. military official had erroneously reported earlier they were returning to the Soto Cano Air Base, 50 miles northwest of Tegucigalpa. The soldiers with less serious injuries were taken by helicopter to Soto Cano, where U.S. troops on military maneuvers in Honduras are frequently based, Jessup said. The uninjured soldiers also were flown to the base, and all leaves there were canceled, Jessup said. The U.S. soldiers have been building roads and airstrips in Honduras, Jessup said. The United States keeps several thousand personnel stationed in Honduras. For about a decade, the U.S. military has frequently conducted exercises in Honduras, which borders Nicaragua. U.S.-backed Contra rebels have been living in Honduran jungle camps near the Nicaraguan border. Kneebone said U.S. government had been on a precautionary alert ahead of April 6, when in 1988 a mob burned the U.S. consulate to protest the extradition of the alleged drug trafficker, Jose Ramon Mata Ballesteros. Kneebone would not say specifically why U.S. government personnel had been put on alert. ``We are always monitoring the security and political environment and so on and we decided to take these precautions,'' he said. Ballesteros, a Honduran citizen said to be linked to Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel, was flown to the United States to stand trial on drug-smuggling charges. At the time, protesters demonstrated for several days, claiming the extradition violated Honduras' constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Spring Protest Draws 1,600 to Nuclear Test Site, 871 Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 1 graf to UPDATE with 871 arrests; pick up 2nd graf, `An estimated ...
DOC.TEXT: Authorities arrested 871 anti-nuclear protesters Saturday for trespassing at an entrance to the Nevada nuclear test site, a federal Department of Energy spokesman said. An estimated 1,600 demonstrators gathered at the highway entrance on the second day of the protest, an event which has been held every spring at the Nevada Test Site for a decade. The arrestees were transported to the town of Beatty, where they were cited for trespassing and released, said DOE spokesman Derek Scammell. There were no injuries, he said. The energy department oversees nuclear weapons tests at the underground site in the desert, about 65 miles northwest of Las Vegas. Kathrin Dress of the American Peace Test organization, said the protesters held a rally earlier in the day and then began their civil disobedience tactics. The protest will continue through Monday, she said. There were 170 arrests on Friday, Scammell said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Governor Says Reagan Comment Probably Triggered FBI, Other Probes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Repeated telephone ...', with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Apodaca, Lutz comment; pick up 12th graf, `Reagan spokesman ...'. Toney is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Toney Anaya said Saturday that his calling then-President Reagan anti-Hispanic during the early 1980s probably triggered a series of federal investigations into Anaya's administration. The prominent Hispanic Democrat, addressing a workshop at the National Association for Chicano Studies annual conference, said he made the comment on an economic trip to Mexico in 1983 or 1984. Anaya, New Mexico's governor from 1983 to 1986, was investigated by the FBI, the U.S. attorney's office in Albuquerque and the Internal Revenue Service. No charges were ever filed against him. He said Saturday that he was asked to comment on Reagan and his policies toward Mexico during a news conference that followed his meeting with Mexico's president during the trip. ``I made the unfortunate statement suggesting that Ronald Reagan was probably the most anti-Hispanic, and they translated that to mean the most anti-Mexican, president we'd ever had,'' he recalled. John Ehrlichman, who was an aide to President Nixon and who lives in Santa Fe, read of Anaya's comment while having breakfast with former Gov. Jerry Apodaca, Anaya said. ``He told Jerry Apodaca, `They're going to get him. The feds are going to get your friend Anaya. They're not going to tolerate that,''' Anaya said. ``It wasn't days after that the first of many federal investigations were kicked off. ``There were 13 FBI investigations altogether, there were three federal grand jury investigations, there was one criminal IRS investigation and two or three instances where we could trace that the CIA had been used in these investigations,'' Anaya said. Anaya said he didn't learn of Ehrlichman's comments until recently, when Apodaca, also a Democrat, related them to him. Apodaca said Saturday night Anaya took Ehrlichman's remarks out of context. Apodaca said Ehrlichman indicated during their conversation that he thought Anaya made a ``major mistake'' in criticizing Reagan while outside the United States. Ehrlichman also said the Reagan administration would ``never let him (Anaya) rest,'' Apodaca said. ``We were simply talking about prevailing attitudes in the administration,'' Apodaca said. Repeated telephone calls to Ehrlichman's Santa Fe home Saturday reached an answering machine. Albuquerque FBI spokesman Doug Belden referred questions on the issue to U.S. Attorney William Lutz, who denied that Anaya's remark prompted the federal investigations. ``It's untrue,'' Lutz said late Saturday. ``It's unfortunate that he (Anaya) would attack President Reagan in that manner.'' Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg in Los Angeles said there would be no comment from the former president, and suggested talking to the FBI. During Anaya's term, Lutz conducted an extensive investigation into the governor's finances. Anaya at the time accused the prosecutor of using a federal grand jury to investigate the governor's involvement in land transactions in New Mexico and Pennsylvania. The IRS investigated Anaya's tax liabilities in 1983 and 1984. According to court documents, the FBI investigated the awarding of a State Fair concession contract after an unsuccessful bidder told agents he'd heard a payoff had been made to Anaya. Anaya said Saturday that the various federal agencies that launched investigations repeatedly leaked information to the news media in their campaign against him, and accused news organizations of ``fanning the flames.'' Anaya, acknowledging his administration made many mistakes, said he believes he was singled out by federal agencies because of differences with the ``right-wing'' Reagan administration over his ``liberal, left-wing'' philosophy. ``We had a progressive agenda and that was not going to set very well with them,'' he said. ``We had taken on Ronald Reagan personally.'' Anaya became the state's 21st governor behind a wave of bipartisan support. But his four years in office were plagued by controversy and criticism, often from the media. By the end of his administration, Anaya's approval rating in public opinion polls had dipped to about 12 percent. He suffered critical reviews for his Good Friday, 1986, proclamation that New Mexico was a state of sanctuary for Central American refugees and his Thanksgiving Eve decision that year to commute the death sentences of the state's five death row inmates. Anaya, who was ineligible for a second consecutive term, was succeeded by Gov. Garrey Carruthers, a Republican. Anaya has remained active in the Democratic Party. He is chairman of the Hispanic Caucus for the Democratic National Committee and a member of the party's national executive committee. He indicated when he left office that he would never again be a political candidate, but said Saturday that that could change.

DOC.HEAD: Buses, Subways, Shutting Down Due to Funding Shortage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 7 grafs to UPDATE with system completely shut down; pick up 9th graf, `About 80 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Buffalo's cash-poor bus and subway system shut down early Sunday after the city transit authority refused to consider a county offer to take over the system. The last bus finished its run at 3:01 a.m., leaving New York state's second-largest city the largest U.S. metropolitan area without any public transit system. More than 120,000 people use Buffalo's system daily. A city labor leader labeled the conflict a ``class struggle'' against selfish suburbanites who didn't want to pay for a system they don't use. Erie County Executive Dennis Gorski said Saturday afternoon he'd asked a Cincinnati management firm to administer the transit system for the county if the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority was willing to yield control. But the authority, meeting with Gorski and city officials Saturday night, refused to take up the offer and voted 7-2 to shut down the system, repeating a similar vote take Wednesday. Gorski had said a county-run system would eliminate all but a small core of bus and subway routes, but would be better than no system at all. ``The alternatives are disastrous,'' he told a news conference. ``You think I want a bus system?'' Gorski asked. ``I don't want it, but I've got to keep it going.'' About 80 percent of the transit system's 1,043 workers had already been laid off by Saturday afternoon, authority spokesman Daryl Rasuli said. On Wednesday, the county legislature rejected a proposed tax on public utilities to fund transit after vigorous opposition from business leaders. The next day, the transit agency's board approved the shutdown 8-1. Attempts Thursday and Friday to put together a bailout plan collapsed. Gorski rejected Mayor James Griffin's proposal to use county sales taxes for transit; the board turned down Gorski's call for sweeping service cuts and reorganizing the transit agency. The utility tax would have raised $9 million for the transit system, which costs about $55 million a year to run. It has been squeezed by declining federal subsidies and had only $89,000 in the bank as of Saturday night. Among the first to be affected by a shutdown would be Buffalo Sabres hockey fans. About 3,000 of the 16,000 fans expected to attend Sunday night's season finale against the Quebec Nordiques would normally have taken the subway to Memorial Auditorium. Taxi companies said they would be overworked because only 375 cabs are licensed to pick up people within city limits. Without a transit system, more than 12,000 public and private schoolchildren who normally ride the bus or subway to school would be stranded, said William Goldbach, assistant city school superintendent for transportation. Goldbach said it would take 240 school buses to carry those children, but said, ``There simply aren't enough bus drivers and vehicles available in the area.'' Some downtown merchants planned to arrange car pools or taxis for their employees, but others said they were waiting to see what happened. About 110 people attended a noontime rally Saturday sponsored by the Buffalo Teachers Federation. Union President Phil Rumore said the shutdown was a ``class struggle'' against wealthy suburbanites and business interests whose lobbying campaign sank the utility proposal. ``We're talking about people that have, saying the have-nots don't need a public transportation system,'' Rumore said. Leonard Braun, New York area manager for the federal Urban Mass Transit Administration, said he knew of no other transit system that had ever been shut down by its own board for lack of funds. But Braun said there was no chance the federal government would come to the rescue, calling the 1974 decision to provide operating subsidies for mass transit ``a mistake.''

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Tension High in Christian Enclave as Civilians Flee
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of civilians fled their embattled Christian enclave Sunday, taking advantage of a lull in two days of ferocious intra-Christian fighting that killed at least 53 people and wounded 133 others. Police said a cease-fire called at midnight Saturday took hold, silencing the heavy guns in the power struggle between rebel army Gen. Michel Aoun and Christian warlord Samir Geagea for mastery of the Christian enclave. A police spokesman said only minor sniping incidents in east Beirut and the highlands of the Kesrouan province in the Christian hinterland marred the truce. Long lines of cars packed with civilians fleeing the enclave with beds, matresses and blankets to Syrian-policed west Beirut formed at a newly reopened crossing through the city's port. The crossing was reopened after a one-year closure, making it the second link between Beirut's Moslem and Christian sectors besides the Museum crossing. Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir said in his Sunday sermon: ``Have we all been hit by triple blindness _ the blindenss of the eye, the blindness of the heart and the blindness of the conscience? ``How can we be blind to (the sight) of homeless families taking shelter in forests?'' The new-round of full-scale warfare broke out at dawn Friday between Aoun's 19,000 army troops and the 6,000 militiamen of Geagea's Lebanese Forces, shattering a March 3 cease-fire that had been threatened by sporadic clashes for weeks. The casualties in the two days of clashes brought the overall toll to 829 killed and 2,289 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea in a bid to crush the only significant challenge to the general's authority in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave.

DOC.HEAD: New Year's Celebrations Come Three Months Late for Quake City
DOC.TEXT: The festivities came three months late, but the earthquake-hit city of Newcastle finally celebrated New Year's Eve. The city about 100 miles north of Sydney was hit Dec. 28 by an earthquake measuring 5.6 on the Richter scale, killing 12 people and destroying many downtown buildings. Most of the New Year's Eve celebrations in the city of 500,000 were canceled as a result, but city officials decided to have a ``re-launching'' of the city on the March 31-April 1 weekend. Hundreds of people turned out Saturday night to several belated New Year's Eve parties thrown by hotels, nightclubs and restaurants in the New South Wales state coastal city.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Jet Goes Down; Pilot Rescued
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy jet crashed in the western Mediterranean during routine operations, but the pilot was quickly rescued, a 6th Fleet spokesman said Sunday. The F-18 Hornet, operating from the U.S.S. Dwight D. Eisenhower, was flying about 28 miles from the aircraft carrier when it went down Saturday afternoon, said Lt. Jim Fallin. An SH-3 Sea King helicopter operating in the area recovered the pilot within 10 minutes and returned to the carrier, Fallin said. The pilot, whose name was not released, was in stable condition. The extent of his injuries was not immediately known. The cause of the accident was under investigation. Fallin said the jet was attached to Fighter Attack Squadron 136, based at Cecil Field, Fla., and that the helicopter was based at the naval air station in Jacksonville, Fla. Both squadrons are embarked on the Eisenhower, which is operating with the 6th Fleet in the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Ruler Urges Mass Weddings And Smaller Dowries To Cut Expenses
DOC.TEXT: The ruler of this Persian Gulf emirate urged his subjects to hold mass weddings and reduce dowries to cut down on stratospheric marriage expenses. ``The problem is that there are several greedy fathers,'' Sheik Sultan bin Mohammed al-Qassimi said in a Saturday night television address, criticizing large dowries often demanded by brides' fathers. Wedding celebrations and dowries can run as high as $28,000 in this oil-rich Persian Gulf nation, prompting some men to seek Indian, Filipino or Egyptian wives who do not insist on the local dowry levels. Sheik Sultan rejected the idea of a law fixing dowries. ``This is not the way to tackle the problem, but it could be solved by mass weddings, and I am personaly ready to attend such parties and have them screened live by television,'' he said. Sultan also urged old men not to marry young foreign women.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Cambodians Found in Boat Off Australian Coast
DOC.TEXT: Customs authorities intercepted a 60-foot boat with 118 people aboard claiming to be Cambodian refugees, officials said Sunday. The boat carrying 100 adults and 18 children was spotted by plane late Saturday and intercepted at the entrance to King Sound, about 1,200 miles north of Perth in Western Australia state, Customs Service spokesman Brian Flanagan said. The spokesman said the boat's occupants claimed the vessel left the southwest Cambodian port of Kompong Saom on March 11 and sailed via Malaysia and Java, a journey of more than 2,000 miles. Those aboard the boat were short on supplies when discovered but healthy, Flanagan said. Customs and quarantine checks were made and further inquiries were under way, but Flanagan did not say if the Cambodians were seeking permission to enter or reside in Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Canceled Opera Rescheduled Amid Outrage by Fans
DOC.TEXT: A surprise strike by theater technicians at the ultramodern Opera-Bastille prompted cancellation of ``The Trojans,'' but outrage among fans who traveled far to see the performance forced officials on Sunday to reschedule it. Some 3,000 people, many from abroad or the provinces, were turned away from a Saturday show after technicians walked out earlier in the day to demand better pay and working conditions. It marked the first cancellation at the glass-and-tile structure since the opening performance of Hector Berlioz's six-hour epic two weeks ago. Administrator George-Francois Hirsch offered to reimburse spectators for the tickets, which ranged from $6.50 to $60. But many paid speculators much more and demanded the scalp price plus the cost of transportation and lodging. In a statement Sunday, the Opera-Bastille promised to honor the tickets for a performance Monday and reimburse those not used. American diva Grace Bumbry was to sing the leading roles of Dido and Cassandra.

DOC.HEAD: Air Routes Between Katmandu and Lhasa Resumed
DOC.TEXT: Air routes between Nepal's capital of Katmandu and the Tibetan capital of Lhasa have been reopened more than a year after being suspended because of anti-Chinese turmoil in Lhasa, a news agency reported. The cross-Himalayan international route was inaugurated in 1987, but closed after violent clashes between Tibetans seeking independence from China and security forces led to the declaration of martial law in Lhasa last March 8. China has since banned almost all visits by foreign diplomats, journalists and tourists not traveling in an organized tour. It now allows tour groups of three or more people to travel to Lhasa, but restricts where they can stay and what they can see. China's Xinhua News Agency said Saturday that a Royal Nepal Airlines Boeing 707 will fly one way from Katmandu to Lhasa every Wednesday from April 25, and an Air China Boeing 707 will make the return trip every Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Tiananmen Square Closed on Day of Proposed Protest
With AM-Mongolia-China, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of yellow-capped schoolchildren marched on Tiananmen Square Sunday, but police barred the general public from entering on a day when dissidents had urged a silent protest in the plaza. The children were bused in to attend ceremonies marking civic efforts to plant trees and flowers for the Asian Games to be held in Beijing in September. Many waved the red flags of the Young Pioneers, a group for teaching social and ideological values. The usual crowd of Sunday visitors to the square, mainly Chinese tourists from outside Beijing, was kept behind police lines on the outskirts of the 100-acre plaza. There were no signs of any attempts to mark the military assault on the student-held square June 4 that left hundreds and perhaps thousands of people dead on the streets of Beijing and ended the seven-week, pro-democracy movement. Campuses in the northwest corner of the city were reportedly quiet. Overseas dissident groups have urged students and other activists to take a ``protest stroll'' on the square on April 1 and April 5 to mourn those killed last year. April 5 is the Qingming Festival, the annual day when Chinese honor their dead. On Qingming in 1976, thousands of Chinese carried wreathes and flowers to Tiananmen to honor Chou En-lai, the beloved premier who died that January, and indirectly protest the ultra-leftist policies of the government. The brutal suppression of that spontaneous show of defiance, in what is now called the first Tiananmen Incident, led to the eventual overthrow of the leftist ``gang of four.'' Organized demonstrations are banned, and the ``stroll'' was proposed to avoid the certain arrests of those participating in any public protests against the repressive policies of the current hard-line government of Premier Li Peng. Chinese sources say Communist Party officials in their work units are telling them to stay away from Tiananmen Square, the symbolic political center of China. There were stepped-up police patrols around the square Saturday night, and police or soldiers on Sunday manned rooftop lookouts around the square, peering down on the crowds with binoculars. Shortly before noon, thousands of People's Liberation Army soldiers who have been bivouacked in the history museum on the east side of the square since June 4 carried out their daily routine of marching across the square to a dining hall on the other side. Also on Saturday, two wreathes dedicated to ``people's heroes,'' an apparent reference to soldiers killed during the attack on Beijing last June, were placed at the base of the revolutionary martyrs' monument in the center of the square. It was not known who brought the wreathes.

DOC.HEAD: Army Pushing Anti-Satellite Arms, But Scaling Back Goal
With AM-NATO Nuclear Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Army is speeding up development of a weapon to shoot down enemy satellites but has quietly dropped its goal of building enough of the ``hit-to-kill'' rockets by the mid-1990s to knock out all Soviet military satellites. The Defense Department asked Congress to nearly triple the project's budget for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1, to $208 million. That would make it one of the fastest growing U.S. weapons programs at a time when Congress is hailing the end of the Cold War as reason to scale back defense spending. The Army estimates the total cost of an anti-satellite system at between $2 billion and $2.5 billion _ most of that to be spent over the next five years. The Army plans to develop two means of attacking satellites: with kinetic, or non-explosive, warheads fired from 30-foot missiles based on U.S. territory, and with ground-based lasers. The Army has put the kinetic warhead system on a fast development track. In February it began soliciting bids from industry to build between 60 and 75 of the weapons. A contractor is scheduled to be selected in July, and full scale development would start in 1992. The laser program is much further behind. While the pace of work on kinetic anti-satellite or ASAT weaponry is picking up, the size of the eventual system has been scaled back, according to Army officials. Brig. Gen. Morgan Jellett, who is in charge of the ASAT program, said that until last December the Army had planned to buy 300 of the weapons, or double the number of Soviet satellites now deployed. In December it was decided that 60 to 75 weapons would be enough to attack the most crucial Soviet space targets, he said. Congressional debate on the defense budget so far this year has focused mainly on bigger-cost projects such as the B-2 bomber, the MX intercontinental ballistic missile and other strategic systems, and on savings from demobilizing troops. The anti-satellite program, however, is beginning to draw more attention. ``I'm going to do everything I can to scrub it,'' Sen. Dale Bumpers, D-Ark., a member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said in an interview. ``It just doesn't make any sense.'' Bumpers said the Soviets' limited anti-satellite capability is no threat to U.S. space interests, and that the Bush administration should take up the Soviets' offer to negotiate a ban on the systems before both sides shell out billions to build them. The ground-based anti-satellite program, as described by its managers in recent interviews at the Army's Strategic Defense Command in Huntsville, Ala., would not violate U.S. arms treaty obligations, yet critics say it could reignite the superpower arms race. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, said in a March 7 floor speech that he feared the United States could be sparking a ``superpower ASAT race'' especially damaging to U.S. space interests, particularly since the Air Force this year retired its fleet of SR-71 Blackbird spy planes, which are less vulnerable to attack than low-earth orbit satellites. Even the Army acknowledges that the Soviets probably would respond to deployment of U.S. anti-satellite, or ASAT, weapons by fielding their own version to knock out U.S. satellites, improving defenses for their own satellites and by developing a weapon to attack the U.S. anti-satellite systems. Jellett sought to play down the ``countermeasures'' issue, saying, ``We don't see those being developed'' anytime soon. Yet an October 1989 Strategic Defense Command document outlining a management plan for ASAT work said that as early as 1996 _ the projected start of deploying a U.S. anti-satellite system _ Moscow would have the technical and economic means to respond by ``enhancing the effectiveness of their force (and) degrading the effectiveness'' of the American system, were it to be operated. The 150-pound kinetic warheads, often called ``hit-to-kill'' projectiles because they would literally destroy a target by ramming it, enjoys the advantage over lasers of being effective in any weather conditions and of making an easily verified ``kill.'' The advantage of the laser is that it would produce less debris in space and could make a covert strike, disabling a satellite by blinding its electronics system but not causing it to explode. Jellett said a laser ASAT weapon could be used, for example, to covertly disable the Soviet Mir space station, which U.S. officials claim could be used for surveillance and military targeting. Jellett said the Mir would be one of the main targets of an ASAT system, but for the purpose of disabling it, not destroying it. The Army work is not part of the Strategic Defense Initiative, known as Star Wars, which would put weapons in space to shoot down ballistic missiles.

DOC.HEAD: New Colt Firearms Owners Considering Resuming AR15 Production
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Grafs 12-17 EMBARGOED for release at 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The new owners of Colt Firearms are weighing whether to resume production of the Colt AR15, the popular U.S.-made, assault-style rifle. The former owners stopped sales to civilians last year when the government banned imports of similar weapons. Ron Stilwell, executive vice president and chief operating officer of what is now called Colt's Manufacturing Co., said the Hartford, Conn.-based company is considering whether to start producing AR15s for civilians again. ``We are evaluating that,'' Stilwell said in an interview. ``We will have some formal statements on it in the future. ``We firmly believe it is a legitimate sporting system and in fact the only system that can be used for certain national target matches,'' he said. The firearms division of Colt Industries was sold March 22 to a group of investors, C.F. Holding. The Colt AR15 was the most popular U.S.-made semiautomatic assault-style rifle when the former owners shut down production for the civilian market in March 1989. The action occurred the day after the federal government imposed a temporary import ban on dozens of foreign-made weapons with similar characteristics. The import ban became permanent last July on 43 styles of rifles. At the time, Colt Industries spokesman Mike Dunn said, ``We want to conform to the spirit of the law although we weren't specifically mentioned in the letter of the law.'' Dunn said late Friday that Colt never resumed production of the AR15 for civilian use. Susan Whitmore of Handgun Control Inc. said she was disappointed that Colt's new management may reverse that decision. ``They're putting profits over public safety,'' Whitmore said. ``We don't want to see one more assault weapon on the streets, and this is just going to add to it.''
DOC.HEAD: EMBARGOED until 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: In 1988, Colt produced 17,368 of the AR15s, according to a list provided by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to Rep. Pete Stark, D-Calif., a gun control advocate. Stark released the list of U.S.-made semiautomatic assault-style rifles and pistols on Sunday. The AR15 represented the largest domestic production of any semiautomatic assault-style rifle or pistol, and copies of it made by other manufacturers totaled 9,411. The ATF list of 78,201 rifles and pistols produced in 1988 included 38,108 rifles and an unknown number of Quality Parts Bushmaster rifles and Ruger Mini 14s, as well as 40,093 pistols. The ban on imports did not include pistols. The second and third largest number of U.S. assault-style weapons produced in 1988 were the Intratec Tec 9 pistols, at 13,770, and the MAC-11 pistols, at 12,273, according to the ATF list. The 26 types of weapons on the list had at least one of the following assault-type characteristics: threaded barrels to accommodate a silencer; flash suppressors that could hide the shooter's position at night and prevent a loss of night vision; provisions for mounting a bayonet; and folding or collapsible stocks. The ATF listed such characteristics when it defined 43 types of foreign-made guns as ``semiautomatic assault rifles'' that it banned from import last July.
DOC.HEAD: END EMBARGOED material
DOC.TEXT: When ATF Director Stephen E. Higgins announced the ban on imports, he said a study had found that the models were ``not being used for sporting uses,'' a requirement for imports. ATF does not control domestically produced weapons. Congress does. The House Judiciary subcommittee on crime approved a bill two weeks ago that would outlaw domestic assault-style weapons. The bill, introduced by Rep. William Hughes, D-N.J., outlaws domestic and foreign-made assault-style rifles. It also would outlaw domestic and imported assault-style pistols which can accept a silencer or a bayonet. The measure, approved 5-3, now awaits action in the House Judiciary Committee. Foreign imports of semiautomatic assault-style rifles were far outnumbering domestic production even before the import ban was imposed, according to ATF. ATF spokesman Jack Killorin said imports of the 43 styles of rifles later banned totaled 84,154 in 1986 and 83,695 in 1987. Although the ATF did not total such imports in 1988, the approved permits and pending requests skyrocketed in 1989, when the weapons were banned. On April 7, 1989, a month after the temporary ban was imposed, there were permits approved or requested to import a total of 926,510 semiautomatic assault-style weapons, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Employee Housing Bill, Originated in Boston, Moves in House
DOC.TEXT: Legislation that would allow employers for the first time to provide union workers with housing assistance is on the fast track toward final passage in Congress this week. The bill, sponsored by a Boston hotel workers union local, calls for a rare amendment to the Taft-Hartley labor law that would allow employers to set aside money to help workers buy or rent housing. ``It's a private-sector initiative. It doesn't cost the government a penny,'' said Bruce Marks, housing director for the 5,000-member Boston Hotel Workers Local 26. ``It's a pure partnership to deal with a major social issue: the lack of affordable housing.'' The bill is more than a boon to unions, Marks said. Large employers around the country have been contacting Local 26 asking for details about the plan; many companies expressing an interest are in areas where living costs are high, making it difficult to recruit and keep employees. The legislation, carrying the unanimous recommendation of the House Education and Labor Committee, is on the ``suspension calendar'' for House floor debate this week _ meaning that it has been deemed non-controversial. In a clear sign of the legislation's ideological breadth, Sens. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, co-sponsored the bill in the Senate, where it already has received final approval. ``It's very important that we join with the Senate in passing this legislation out of Congress, and I think the full House will support it unanimously,'' said Rep. William Clay, D-Mo., chairman of the labor-management relations subcommittee and the House sponsor of the bill. Housing Secretary Jack Kemp and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole are strongly behind the bill, according to Clay and union officials. Taft-Hartley, the nation's overriding labor relations law for 43 years, includes anti-corruption provisions that prohibit management from making direct payments to unions except for certain purposes, including employee education, health and retirement. The amendment, up for a vote Tuesday, would add housing to that list. In December 1988 the hotel workers negotiated an agreement with nine Boston hotels calling for wage and work improvements and an unprecedented housing trust fund. The agreement required the hotels to contribute 5 cents per hour for every employee into the trust. Workers would not have to contribute. If Congress approves, the fund, now estimated at about $1 million, will be available to pay loan collaterals, help with down payments, reduce mortgage interest rates, or pay apartment fees or security deposits. Workers will apply to a joint union-management board for assistance. A formula based on the employee's financial need will be used to determine whether or how much money the worker receives. The contract stipulates that if the Taft-Hartley amendment is not made by May 31, the trust fund money will revert to a fund used for conventional union benefits. A particular challenge the union faced was a general hands-off policy in Congress toward the Taft-Hartley Act. ``We've always had a fear of opening up the law,'' Clay said.

DOC.HEAD: Mood in Vilnius Grim as Press Leaves, Army Arrives
DOC.TEXT: The mood in the Lithuanian capital was grim Sunday as the Soviet army moved in dozens of additional armored personnel carriers just hours after a threatening statement from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The combination of the warning, the reinforcements, Friday's seizure of a Lithuanian government building by Soviet troops and the Soviet Union's drive to remove foreign correspondents from the republic by Sunday night had many people worried that martial law would be imposed within days. ``I fear they are going to start shooting,'' said one middle-aged Lithuanian woman. Last week, Gorbachev said he would use force only if there was a threat to life. Since then, Soviet authorities have complained of several sniper attacks on soldiers. Lithuanian officials said they can find no evidence to support the allegations and many fear that the reports are being created to serve as a pretext for a military crackdown. The silence from Western nations in the face of these moves left little hope of aid from abroad. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said last Tuesday the U.S. government did not want ``to inflame the situation'' by issuing comments on the Soviet army's actions in Lithuania. The army rounded up at least 23 Lithuanian deserters last week and has occupied several buildings. In London, an assistant to Lithuania's prime minister, Laima Andrikiene, was kept waiting while Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher spoke with Gorbachev on the telephone. When Thatcher's conversation with the Soviet president ended, Ms. Andrikiene's appointment was canceled, another member of the delegation, parliamentarian Emanuelis Zingeris said. Gorbachev has said he fears a break-up of the Soviet Union could result in chaos and violent conflict. He has said it would uproot many of the 60 million people who do not live in their ancestral lands. Saturday night, Gorbachev urged Lithuanian leaders to reverse their republic's declaration of independence, saying they must recognize their responsibilty for the Lithuanian people's ``security and well-being, for the state of democracy in the whole country, and stability in the world.'' He warned that if they refuse, ``the developments may have grave consequences for all of us.'' Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said Saturday night Gorbachev was ``demanding impossible things,'' but said he would send a delegation to Moscow on Monday to try to begin negotiations. On Sunday, the last foreign correspondents were being rousted out of the republic. Hundreds of journalists from across the world obeyed the Soviet government's order to depart, fearing the loss of their Moscow bureaus if they refused. Many said they were depressed at being forced to leave Lithuania after Gorbachev's warning. ``You do get this very sick feeling in your stomach that as soon as we leave ... it's not going to be pretty,'' said Jonathan Sanders of CBS. ``People in the (Lithuanian) TV station are very nervous,'' he said. Sanders said the Lithuanian journalists expect their reporting of the Moscow-Vilnius war of nerves to be halted as soon as foreign networks are no longer on hand to record a Soviet takeover of their stations. The Soviet army reinforced its garrison in central Vilnius Sunday with at least 45 armored personnel carriers. ``It's the same Brezhnev doctrine at work as in Czechoslovakia,'' only this time, Gorbachev is moving ``with a smile, slowly and easily,'' said Algimantas Cekuolis, editor of ther Lithuanian newspaper Gintasis Krastas, who has become a de facto spokesman for the independent government. He was referring to the doctrine under which late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev justified the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia. Despite the pressure, Lithuanian officials say they are convinced they will last longer than Gorbachev's authority over a splintering empire. ``Our tactics are to hold on a couple of months,'' Cekuolis said. He said he hopes for support from other Soviet republics moving toward independence and from other democratically minded legislators just elected to the Russian parliament. Lithuanians also said Gorbachev risks the loss of respect in the Soviet Union and in the world if he is unable to assert his authority without resorting to force. ``They are compromising the leadership of the Soviet Union,'' Landsbergis said.

DOC.HEAD: Boredom, Relaxation For Unrepentant Aquino Foes
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: An armed guard watched over prisoners who tried to topple President Corazon Aquino in December. His shirt was emblazoned with the face of a mutiny leader and their motto: ``Our dreams shall never die.'' Other guards mingled freely with more than 50 officers jailed at Camp Crame following the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt. Guards shared meals with family and friends of the inmates during visitors' day on a recent Sunday. The prisoners are among 2,143 officers and enlisted men in custody at various camps nationwide in connection with the strongest and bloodiest bid so far to topple Mrs. Aquino's four-year administration. Nearly 250 officers and enlisted men remain at large following the coup attempt, in which at least 113 people were killed and more than 600 wounded. Investigators admit, however, that many others may have secretly supported the coup attempt. ``We don't know the extent of their support,'' said one prosecutor who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We are just working on what we have _ the tip of the iceberg.'' Despite the gravity of the offenses, the atmosphere at Camp Crame was more of a family reunion than a maximum-security stockade. Guards addressed senior detainees with a respectful ``sir'' and played with children of the inmates. Four months after the coup attempt, only 81 officers have been charged. The rest are still undergoing investigation while in custody under conditions ranging from confinement in a stockade to being restricted to military camps. Those at large include Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, the charismatic former lieutenant colonel, whose likeness was emblazoned on the guard's shirt. Other fugitives include former Brig. Gen. Jose Zumel, once superintendent of the Philippine Military Academy, and navy Commodore Domingo Calajate, valedictorian of his academy class. No date has been set for trials, and sessions involving defendants in previous coup attempts dragged on for months before verdicts were returned. In the meantime, soldiers who had been among the cream of the officer corps wile away their time at stockades discussing the country's future and drafting position papers on alternative government. They break the monotony with an occasional bottle of smuggled liquor. ``We like it here,'' joked one senior officer who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We're just waiting for the next coup.'' Like prisoners of war, inmates maintain a chain of command. At the Camp Crame stockade, air force Brig. Gen. Jose Commendador, who led the takeover of an air base near Cebu City, serves as the acknowledged ``supremo.'' Commendador even counsels prisoners and their wives about family problems, once chiding a wife for not visiting her husband at every occasion. Mutineers make no effort to hide their contempt for the military hierarchy and their former commander-in-chief, Mrs. Aquino. In one cell, detainees exercise by punching a makeshift bag adorned with sketches of the faces of the chief of staff, Gen. Renato de Villa, and Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos, who has crushed six attempts to oust Mrs. Aquino. Inmates named one cellblock the ``De Villa Detention Center'' and another the ``Ramos Detention Center,'' and joked that's where they would confine the two if another coup attempt succeeds. Cell walls are plastered with posters bearing rebel slogans. One of them, titled ``A Filipino's Prayer,'' was patterned after a prayer to the Virgin Mary: ``Hail Cory, an utter disgrace, the U.S. is with you ... pray for us rebels, coup plotters, loyalists and activists now and at the hour of the next coup or the strategic stalemate.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Demonstrate Against Romanian President
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of flag-waving demonstrators shouting ``Down With Communism!'' marched through downtown Bucharest Sunday demanding the resignation of the nation's interim president. The demonstrators marched to government headquarters in Victory Square holding brightly colored kites and chanting ``Down With Iliescu!'' referring to President Ion Iliescu. Before the rally they gathered at University Square to kneel and pray. The square was the site of heavy fighting during the revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22. Speakers at Victory Square accused Iliescu of being a ``closet Communist'' and of sympathizing with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Iliescu is head of the National Salvation Front, the dominant force in the provisional National Unity Council, which will rule Romania until a new government is chosen after national elections scheduled for May 20. Pre-election polls indicate that the Front is the most popular political alliance in the country. The elections will be Romania's first free balloting since 1947, when the Communist Party imposed its single-party dictatorship. The demonstrators were joined by hundreds of bystanders as they marched through downtown Bucharest, stopping at the major sites of the Dec. 22 uprising. Hundreds of troops and paramilitary policemen stood guard at the government headquarters and the entrance to the building was blocked by a line of armored personnel carriers. ``We no longer need communism _ let the face of Gorbachev disappear'' said Haralamb Zupascu, a former political prisoner and one of the organizers of Sunday's demonstration. ``Say NO to the neo-Communist dictatorship of the National Salvation Front!'' read one banner held aloft by the crowd. Meanwhile, the leader of the opposition Liberal Union party, Ion Bratianu, declared his candidacy for president. On Saturday, Radu Cimpeanu, the leader of the National Liberal Party, announced his candidacy in the presidential race.

DOC.HEAD: Former DEA Agent Says Drug War a Sham
DOC.TEXT: Mike Levine is angry. The longtime Drug Enforcement Administration undercover agent contends the war on drugs is a sham run by ``suits'' in Washington who care more about their jobs than about winning the war or preserving the lives of agents on the street. Levine says they killed the better part of his last major case while needlessly putting his life and the lives of other agents in jeopardy. If the plan had been carried out, he says, agents could have arrested leaders of the Corporation, which runs Bolivia's cocaine operations, and a major Bolivian money launderer in Panama while seizing at least 38 tons of cocaine at secret air strips in Bolivia. But it was not to be. So a frustrated Levine, who retired from the DEA last year, wrote a book about his experiences called ``Deep Cover.'' ``The whole drug war has now become a political grab bag,'' Levine said in a recent interview. ``All of these people (leading the war on drugs) have their arms in this grab bag for every reason you can imagine.'' The book focuses on a case _ Operation Trifecta _ that ended in early 1988. It resulted in convictions and long sentences for several Mexican and Bolivian drug traffickers. But Levine says it could have done much more if bureaucrats had not stood in the way of his plan to buy 15,000 kilos (more than 30,000 pounds) of cocaine with $5 million, allowing him to penetrate the upper reaches of the Bolivian cocaine trade. Among the book's contentions: _The agent in charge of DEA's Panama office, Alfredo ``Fred'' Duncan, suggested that the undercover agents stay at a Marriott hotel, even though the drug traffickers called it the ``DEA hotel'' and refused to do business there. On a later trip, DEA headquarters insisted that the agents again conduct business at the Marriott. _Duncan was asked several times to keep the Corporation's alleged money launderer in Panama, Remberto Rodriguez, under surveillance. But when Levine and another agent flew to Panama in early 1988 to arrest Rodriguez, Duncan professed ignorance about who he was, where he could be found and even that he'd been asked to keep track of him. _Two months before final meetings between the agents and the drug traffickers occurred at an undercover house in La Jolla, Calif., near San Diego, U.S. Customs officials had escorted TV news crews through the home. The crews filmed the attic where video monitors and other eavesdropping equipment was set up, and even took photos of lamps with hidden cameras. _Reporters also were on hand for the arrests of the Mexican and Bolivian drug traffickers near the La Jolla home, and the news was out all over Latin America long before the agents could arrest Rodriguez or raid the Bolivian air strips. By the time Levine arrived in Panama, Rodriguez had disappeared and the air strips had been abandoned. _The DEA balked at Levine's plan because its top officials had sold Congress on the value of Operation Snowcap, in which DEA agents are sent to South America to help local officials eradicate coca crops and cocaine processing laboratories. If his operation had been successful, Levine says, it would have revealed that Operation Snowcap was a waste of money and unnecessarily put agents in harm's way. The only reason any of the plan went forward was because Customs embarrassed DEA into it, offering to put up the money, Levine says. The DEA has been tight-lipped about the book, even though the book criticizes such high-ranking officials as acting administrator Terry Burke, chief of operations David Westrate and Duncan. ``We feel it's inappropriate to debate the merits of the specifics of his book with anyone and we are not going to have anything such as this distract us from our mission,'' DEA spokesman Frank Shults said. ``It's unfortunate that a former narcotics agent has taken on all of his former colleagues,'' Shults added. ``As an individual, his view is limited to that of an individual and he was never in a position to know the best direction that the agency should take.'' At Customs, spokesman David Hoover said, ``We don't have an official reaction to his book. It's not a cause celebre around here.'' To Jim Dozier, the book was real. Now the county attorney in Montgomery County, Texas, Dozier spent eight years in the DEA after two years with Customs, all of it in drug enforcement. ``Many things rang true in the case that made me grin with frustrations I had in the past with certain cases,'' Dozier said in an interview. Dozier said he could recall ``many times when you have something good in hand'' that had to ``go through 15 lines of bureaucrats who hadn't been on the line in years.'' Their notion of fiscal restraint once put his life in danger, he said. When he traveled overseas to work on a possible drug connection at a gambling casino, the government gave him only about $100 to gamble with. The drug traffickers, meanwhile, were putting $50,000 in chips on the table. Dozier said he allayed their suspicions somewhat by claiming he didn't gamble, but adds, ``There aren't too many people like that who don't gamble.'' The moral: ``If you want to swim around with a bunch of ducks, you've got to look like a duck.''

DOC.HEAD: Independent Data Agency Won't Happen, EPA Chief Says
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency predicted Sunday the Senate will respond to a threatened veto by President Bush and reject a House-passed effort to establish a politically independent bureau for collecting and analyzing environmental data. ``We do not want an independent agency that we have no control over'' as part of a proposed Cabinet-level Department of the Environment replacing the EPA, Administrator William K. Reilly said. ``We are confident the Senate will not have a provision of that sort,'' the EPA chief said. President Bush in January endorsed a congressional effort already afoot to elevate EPA to Cabinet status. However, the House, in approving the bill last week, said it wanted an independent Bureau of Environmental Statistics in the new department headed by a civil servant who could be dismissed only for malfeasance. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater immediately raised the threat of a veto, saying the House bill ``gives a degree of independence to this unit of the agency which we feel is unconstitutional.'' Fitzwater expressed confidence the administration could sustain a veto in Congress. Reilly, appearing on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program, called the proposal for an independent data agency a ``slight'' to the EPA and said it suggests ``that we're not capable of developing quality information and doing environmental statistical collection.'' ``One inference I draw from the efforts by some Democrats in the House to create such an entity is that they don't expect to be in power very soon,'' he said. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., who as chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations is the chief sponsor of the independent data agency provision, said it would put a halt to ``conflicts of interest'' that had raised questions in the past about EPA analyses. Conyers cited a case last year in which EPA scientists were directed by the White House Office of Management and Budget to change their testimony to Congress about global warming because it did not fit with the administration's view. Under the House-passed bill, the Bureau of Environmental Statistics would function much like the Bureau of Labor Statistics does under the umbrella of the Labor Department. Its head would be named to a four-year term and would not be subject to dismissal except for malfeasance. Just as with Bureau of Labor Statistics, administration officials, including the secretary of the department, would not have authority to review or alter reports by the new environmental data bureau before they are released. A similar bill elevating EPA to Cabinet status has been approved by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee but has not yet been taken up by the full Senate. Both Bush and sponsors of the measure had hoped to have it ready for his signature by April 22, the 20th anniversary of the first Earth Day celebration. Neither version of the bill envisions a significant expansion of EPA as a department rather than a regulatory agency. EPA now has a staff of about 16,000 employees and budget of $5.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Civilians Flee as Cease-Fire Begins
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of civilians fled Lebanon's Christian enclave Sunday as a cease-fire ended two days of fierce fighting between rival Christian forces that left 63 dead and 133 wounded. Police said an uneasy calm reigned over the major warfronts in rain-drenched east Beirut and the fog-shrouded highlands of Kesrouan province in the Christian hinterland northeast of the capital. The truce was negotiated by a three-man Christian mediation committee backed by the Vatican. It is the 15th cease-fire in two months. A police spokesman said many villages have been nearly wiped out by shellfire and large sections of several posh mountain resort towns were gutted, ``yet neither side has gained a single inch of territory.'' The spokesman, who could not be named under standing regulations, said the truce was ``allowing rescue workers to remove bodies and civilians to flee. The truce seems to be holding, at least momentarily.'' The latest round of fighting broke out at dawn Friday, pitting Gen. Michel Aoun's 19,000 army troops against Christian warlord Samir Geagea's 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces militia. The two days of fighting raised the number of casualties to 839 dead and 2,289 wounded since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea to stamp out the main challenge to his authority in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. The two sides battled with artillery, tanks and multi-barreled rocket launchers. Despite pitched battles and house-to-house fighting, Aoun's army failed to break through Lebanese Forces defenses in Kesrouan or east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh and Karantina districts, leaving Geagea in full control of two-thirds of the Christian enclave. Aoun and his troops remain in Metn province, with no airport or harbor to resupply. Hostile Syrian troops ring all overland inlets to his territory. ``The showdown remains inconclusive on the battleground, but Geagea is rapidly emerging as the political victor,'' said a long-time Lebanon analyst, who requested anonymity. Tens of thousands of residents emerged from basements and bomb shelters at first light in east Beirut to examine the destruction wreaked on their homes and businesses by the two days of fighting. Thousands hurriedly packed beds, mattresses and blankets into taxis and fled to the Syrian-controlled western sector of the divided capital. Others stockpiled food, water and powder milk, fearing the cease-fire would not last. Police estimate that up to one-third of the enclave's 1 million inhabitants have fled since Feb. 1. ``I couldn't risk staying. They're definitely reloading to start all over again,'' said Maroun Bustani, a Christian pharmacist, after he fled with his wife and two children into west Beirut. In a Sunday sermon, Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir asked: ``Have we all been hit by triple blindness _ the blindness of the eye, the blindness of the heart and the blindness of the conscience?'' ``How can we be blind to (the sight) of homeless families taking shelter in forests?'' he said at the chapel in Bkirki, where hundreds of families had taken refuge in the pine forest. Aoun and Geagea are both Maronites, a Catholic sect that has dominated Lebaonon's political life since independence from France in 1943. Geagea has backed the presidency of Elias Hrawi, a Maronite, who was elected by parliament Nov. 24 with a mandate to enforce an Arab league-brokered peace plan to resolve Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The accord gives Moslems an equal share of power with Christians. Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister but the general has held out in the presidential palace in a Christian enclave east of Beirut, claiming Hrawi's election is unconstitutional. Aoun also rejected the Arab League peace plan saying it did not guarantee the total withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Bensonhurst Racial Attack Going to Trial
DOC.TEXT:
The alleged ringleader of a white mob charged in the killing of a black teen-ager goes on trial Monday along with the accused triggerman as prosecutors try to recover from a series of setbacks in their case. Assistant Brooklyn District Attorney Bruce McIntyre, who had been tipped to present opening arguments, abruptly quit as trial strategies were being finalized last week, saying he resented being a ``token'' black at the prosecution table. Prosecutors endured another blow three weeks ago when John Vento, 21, an important witness in the slaying, backed out of a deal and decided to face second-degree murder charges rather than testify against his friends. Seven other young white men from Bensonhurst have been charged in the Aug. 23 slaying of Yusuf Hawkins, a black 16-year-old who was shot after he went with three friends into the largely Italian neighborhood in south Brooklyn to look at a used car.
Judge Thaddeus Owens ruled last week that alleged triggerman Joseph Fama, 19, and alleged ringleader Keith Mondello, 20, would be the first to stand trial, prosecutors said. Jury selection begins Monday. Both men are charged with two counts of murder and face 25 years to life in prison if convicted. Five of the others have been charged with murder and other crimes, and the sixth with assault. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes says he is baffled by McIntyre's resignation and regrets Vento's change of heart, but insists he's confident he has a case he can win. Vento's unexpected defection led prosecutors to seek, and get, a one-month delay in the start of the trials. On Monday, the judge plans to speed the proceedings by impaneling two juries. The panels will sit side by side in the courtroom, with one deciding the fate of Fama and the other considering the case of Mondello. There may be as many as six trials, defense lawyers and prosecutors say. The murder, labeled racial from the outset by police and prosecutors, sparked a furor across the city. It is widely viewed as the most serious racial incident in the city since a December 1986 attack in New York's Howard Beach neighborhood in which a black man, chased by a gang of whites, ran onto a highway and was struck and killed by car. The Bensonhurst killing apparently was ignited by a dispute between Mondello and a former girlfriend, Gina Feliciano. As word raced through the neighborhood that Miss Feliciano had invited a group of black and Hispanic friends to her 18th birthday party, Mondello allegedly recruited some of his friends to take on what they saw as intruders on their turf. The gang of some 30 whites, many armed with baseball bats, mistook Hawkins and his three teen-age friends, all of them black, as the expected outsiders and set upon them. As the gang surrounded the four youths, Fama allegedly stepped in with his gun and fired four shots, three of which struck Hawkins and killed him. The mob scattered when the shots were fired and Hawkins' companions _ who are expected to testify at the trials _ were not hurt.

DOC.HEAD: Trump's Billion-Dollar Casino Opens Monday
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump opens the world's largest gambling hall Monday, and his heavily leveraged billion-dollar Taj Mahal Casino Resort needs to rake $1 million a day off the Boardwalk just to pay its debt. Its 11 competitors, meanwhile, worry and wonder whether the 42-story Taj Mahal's 3,000 slot machines, 12 restaurants and $10,000-a-night suites will bring new customers to the Boardwalk or steal away old business. Analysts estimate the Taj Mahal must bring in at least $1 million a day to pay expenses plus interest on $675 million in bonds Trump took out to finish the casino he took over from Resorts International in November 1988 after five years of sporadic construction. The casino is opening at a time when Atlantic City's gaming market has flattened and new competition for the betting dollar is coming from ``theme'' casinos in Nevada and from new state lotteries elsewhere. Trump, who owns Trump Plaza and Trump Castle casino-hotels, said the Taj Mahal's 120,000-square-foot floor and the novelty of a gambling hall named for the 16th century Indian mausoleum will let him exceed the $1 million figure. ``The Taj Mahal will be beyond everything else,'' he said. ``The three (casinos) occupy a similar niche. They're luxury properties that cater to high rollers and everybody interested in a good time.'' Not everybody sees the Taj Mahal as a magnificent success beyond its first months, when interest is high and the weather is warm. ``When the property first opens, my guess is it will do no wrong,'' said Marvin B. Roffman, a former gaming analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott whose published remarks about the Taj Mahal led to his firing when Trump complained to the brokerage company. ``The big question mark is, is it sustainable in the winter months?'' Roffman said. Roffman said he expects a Taj Mahal ``win,'' or gross revenues, of $35 million to $40 million in its first month. The win does not take expenses into account, and thus is not profit. The Mirage Hotel, helped by the Sugar Ray Leonard-Roberto Duran fight, took in more than $40 million in its first month of operation in Las Vegas. Caesars Hotel Casino set Atlantic City's record with a win of $32.8 million last July. Last year's win leader for the year _ Trump Plaza _ took in $305.7 million. Daniel Lee, a gaming analyst with First Boston, also predicted a $35 million to $40 million win for the first month and expects that pace to continue. He said he expects a $375 million win for the year, exceeding $1 million a day, for the Taj Majal. ``Is it too leveraged? Probably not,'' Lee said. ``Do I think he'll default? Certainly not.'' State Division of Gaming Enforcement Director Anthony Parrillo said the Taj Mahal has proven it will be financially sound for the one-year licensing period. ``Atlantic City had been loaded with debt on these properties,'' Parrillo said. ``The same can be said for the Taj. That's not to say it can't be profitable.'' Casino president Walter J. Haybert said the 5,200-seat Mark Etess Arena, named after one of two top Taj Mahal executives who died in a October helicopter crash, will draw convention and event business in lean months. Beyond the gold, green and blue minarets that festoon the casino and give it that certain Taj Mahal flavor are the city's 11 other casinos, worried about losing business after a year of only 2.6 percent growth. The Showboat Hotel Casino and Merv Griffin's Resorts Casino Hotel, which are bookends to the Taj Mahal, are banking on their new neighbor to bring customers to what has been the relatively barren north end of the Boardwalk. Trump said the Taj Mahal might take away rivals' business in the short run but would lead to long-term growth in a market that had its first decline in tourist visits since the first casino opened in 1978. Casino Association President Thomas Carver said the other casinos feel the Taj Mahal could cause a ``tremendous spurt in the market,'' but also approach the opening with ``a lot of trepidation.'' ``Everybody knows that the concentration of interest will be in that general area,'' Carver said, referring to the northern end of the Boardwalk. ``The specific gravity of the town may change.'' The wild card in the game is Trump himself and his name-in-the-news quality that accelerated with his recent marital breakup. Trump admits the gossip accounts for many of the 1,500 media credentials issued for the opening. ``It's a strange phenomena but someday we'll figure it all out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Weighing Lower Milk Subsidies for Excess Butter
DOC.TEXT: Americans' desire for low-fat food is posing a new threat in Congress to dairy farmers whose surplus butter ends up in government warehouses because consumers don't want it on their table. Under consideration as part of the 1990 farm bill is a change in the price support structure that would cut into the subsidies received by farmers who produce more milkfat than the market will bear. Introduced by Reps. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, and Steve Gunderson, R-Wis., the plan would penalize farmers who produce more than their limit as part of a nationwide ceiling on milkfat production. However, the bill also would raise the support price _ what the government pays for 100 pounds of milk if the market price falls below that amount _ from the current $10.10 per 100 pounds of milk to $10.60. ``While we do that, we also get at the milkfat problem currently plaguing the dairy industry,'' said Gunderson. Currently, price supports drop by 50 cents per 100 pounds when government purchases for the year are estimated to exceed 5 billion pounds. The Bush administration wants to continue that system which, according its estimates, could lead to price supports dropping to $8.60 by 1993. Gunderson's and Stenholm's bill would prevent the administration from reducing the price support any lower than $10.10. The National Milk Producers Federation, which represents dairy cooperatives, wants a support of $10.60 with no lower price available. Rep. Harold Volkmer, D-Mo., is leading the support for that position. The House Agriculture dairy subcommittee on dairy, which Stenholm chairs and Gunderson vice chairs, has set aside Tuesday for approving the language that would be the dairy title of the 1990 farm bill. The solution to the milkfat problem is contentious. Some subcommittee members and the Bush administration both contend the Stenholm-Gunderson plan is unworkable. Basically, the plan calls for a two-tiered price support system. If the government buys more than 7 billion pounds of milk products that include 260 million pounds of milkfat and 600 million pounds of powered milk and cheese, the system begins to operate. Farmers would get the higher support price for a certain percentage of their milk and a sharply lower price for the overproduced portion. Tom Theiding, an aide to Gunderson, said farmers could reduce the amount of milkfat they produce by about one-tenth of 1 percent simply by changing the feed cows eat. But he acknowledged that cows have been bred to produce more fat and changing that to higher protein production will take time. Under the Stenholm-Gunderson bill, farmers would be told to annually reduce their milkfat production from the previous year, Theilding said. ``We're trying to get an incentive out to the farmer that says,`don't give us butter,''' he said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: A tour bus carrying singer Willie Nelson slammed into a car that crossed into its path on a slush-covered highway Sunday morning, police said. No one in the Nelson bus was injured but the driver of the car died. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Paul Leonard Burtch, 20, of Lower Sackville, Novia Scotia, was killed when his car crossed the center line of the Trans Canada Highway six miles east of Truro. Nelson and four others who were on the bus were not injured. They were on their way to Newfoundland for concerts as part of an eastern Canadian tour. Police said the bus was badly damaged but Nelson was able to make other travel arrangements. They said their investigation was continuing.

The $15 program was airbrushed to erase some laugh lines and gray hairs, but the 60,000 crowd reveled in the real thing when Paul McCartney performed at Memorial Stadium. Fans snatched up $300 worth of programs in less than three minutes in a buying frenzy ``straight out of `Jaws,''' said salesman Eli Glick. The program featured photographs of the 47-year-old former Beatle that made him look at least 10 years younger.
