But many fans at Saturday's concert were as gray-haired as their idol. ``Fandom is for all ages,'' said Vivian Kiss, 40, who met McCartney in 1983 after haunting the Oxford Street studio in London where he recorded ``Give My Regards to Broad Street.'' For Jim Juanis, 36, the concert had a different significance. He was 13 years old when the Beatles played Shea Stadium in New York, and his mother wouldn't let him attend. ``She said I was too young,'' Juanis said, adding: ``Paul McCartney crosses all age barriers. You can compare his music to Gershwin or Beethoven. He is a musician for all time.''

Fans snapped up 2,500 tickets to Madonna concerts in the first minute of sales and 60,000 tickets in just over one hour, a ticket agency said. ``She's a sensational performer and her popularity is huge,'' said Fred Rosen, chief executive officer of Ticketmaster, the nation's largest computerized ticket outlet. The sultry pop idol was to perform two concerts May 11 and 12 at the Los Angeles Sports Arena. When those sold out Saturday, two more shows were added for May 13 and 15 and they also sold out, said publicist Larry Solters. Tickets for a fifth date, May 16, will go on sale Wednesday. In all, half a million tickets went on sale nationwide for Madonna concerts in New York, New England, Philadelphia, Chicago and Houston.

Publicity grabbing promoters of a crawfish festival have mailed packages containing live crustaceans to journalists and celebrities, including David Letterman and Arsenio Hall. Ten 5-pound packages worth about $400 were mailed out last week to help publicize the annual Pawleys Island Crawfish Festival on April 27-28, said promoter Cal Harrelson. Other mailing-list fortunates included weathermen Willard Scott of the NBC ``Today'' show, Spencer Christian of ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' and syndicated columnist Lewis Grizzard. Directions on how to cook the crawfish and ``how to pinch the tails and suck the head'' were enclosed, Harrelson said Friday. The boxes contained packets of spices, a warning label advising against consumption of dead crawfish, and a plea of caution when placing them in boiling water ``because they tend to jump around a bit,'' he said. About 30,000 people attended last year's feast and Harrelson said he hopes to break the 50,000 mark this year.

Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II's husband, attended a gala benefit performance of Andrew Lloyd Webber's new Broadway musical ``Aspects of Love'' and went backstage to greet the cast. Proceeds from Saturday's performance at the Broadhurst Theater will benefit three youth organizations. The prince visited as patron and trustee of the Duke of Edinburgh's Award Scheme. The show opens April 8, but preview performances began two weeks ago. The prince met Lloyd Webber and his wife, actress Sarah Brightman, and members of the cast. The prince, who is also president of the Worldwide Fund for Nature, said in a speech Friday at the United Nations that population growth has created an environmental crisis that, in unchecked, could be ``more devastating than any nuclear holocaust.''

Entertainer Dolly Parton recently sold her three-bedroom home in the Hollywood Hills, at close to the $2 million asking price, according to her real estate agent. Miss Parton also has a home in Tennessee, where she spends most of her time, but she is likely to buy another house in Los Angeles after she completes a 70-city concert tour with Kenny Rogers. Miss Parton bought the house, just off the Sunset Strip, about four years ago, and has thoroughly remodeled the place, said agent June Scott. ``It was a very personal house to enhance her relaxation, and she liked it so much that at one point she nearly didn't sell it,'' Ms. Scott said. The buyers were described only as ``a local couple.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Rabbi Says Anti-Semitism on Rise Following Ceausescu Fall
DOC.TEXT: The firing squad that executed Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu last December killed official anti-Semitism in that nation, only to allow a more dangerous form to surface, the country's chief rabbi says. ``Before, the anti-Semitism was from above. Now, it's from below,'' Rabbi Moses Rosen said. Rosen was in Washington to ask for help in combating the anti-Semitism finding new expression among Romanians since the revolution that overthrew Ceausescu. Rosen, the leader of Romania's Jewish community for the last 42 years, met with an old friend _ Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger. Eagleburger in 1984 interceded on the elderly cleric's behalf when Ceausescu was about to arrest him. Rosen said he described to Eagleburger the resurgence of the fascist Iron Guard organization, which conducted pogroms against Romania's Jews in 1941. Speaking in an interview, Rosen said young disciples of the organization have been coming back to Romania from exile in the United States, Canada and other countries. In Canada, he said, some of the group members received paramilitary training. There were 400,000 Jews left in Romania after World War II, about half the pre-war population. Now only 20,000 remain, most of them over 60. Rosen said he had received threats on his life in letters mailed to his home in Bucharest, as have other Romanian Jews. A synagogue was destroyed recently in a town near the border with Hungary, he said. Rosen said that while he had been reassured by the government that it would punish those responsible for anti-Semitic acts, he was not sure how effective the authorities could be. ``There is a power vacuum, a breakdown of law and order,'' he said. This was evident in an outbreak of vicious street violence earlier this month between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians in the province of Transylvania. Echoing a scathing editorial Rosen wrote recently in one of his country's major newspapers, the rabbi said of the Jews' enemies: ``What do they want from us? What harm does it cause if we wait for our graves to be here, next to those of our parents and forefathers?''

DOC.HEAD: Season Premiere of First Part of Wagner's Ring Cycle
DOC.TEXT: The curse that hangs over Wagner's magic golden ring and brings misfortune to his characters seemed to extend to the production as well at the Metropolitan Opera's first performance of ``Das Rheingold'' this season. At a crucial moment in the final scene on Saturday night, the greedy giant Fafner reaches to snatch the ring from a pile of treasure. Instead, it fell to the stage and rolled away from him, coming to rest perilously close to the orchestra pit. There it remained for the rest of the opera, symbolic of how this production, for all its musical splendor, remains hampered by stage effects that sometimes seem amateurish or misguided. The Met wanted a traditional, literal-minded `Ring Cycle,'' free from the psychological and political interpretations fashionable in Europe in recent years. That's OK, but it puts a tremendous burden on the sets and projections by Guenther Schneider-Siemssen and the lighting by Gil Wechsler to seem truly magical where Wagner called for magic. In Scene Three of ``Rheingold,'' for example, the vicious dwarf Alberich is supposed to change into a serpent, then a toad, by means of a helmet fashioned out of the gold he has stolen from the Rhinemaidens. Surely in an age of stage wizardry that has brought us ``Phantom of the Opera,'' his transformation could be managed more convincingly than to have him visibly sneak off stage behind a cloud of smoke each time. The serpent, by the way, has a new wrinkle this season _ he emits showers of sparks that make him livelier, if not particularly scary. We'll see if there has been any similar tinkering with the dragon that figures in the third opera of the cycle, ``Siegfried.'' Up to now, he has looked rather disgusting but not realistic enough to be frightening. Musically, the performance, with a mostly familiar cast, was just about all one could hope for. James Morris' Wotan remains a pillar of vocal strength, and Ekkehard Wlaschiha's Alberich was a good match for him. Siegfried Jerusalem repeated his wonderfully slimy interpretation of Loge, the god of fire, but he sounded more raspy than mellifluous in his upper register. That doesn't matter much for Loge, but it makes one wonder how he'll cope with the heroic demands of the young Siegfried, a part he'll sing for the first time at the Met in a couple of weeks. Helga Dernesch found Fricka, Wotan's nagging wife, a congenial role for her waning vocal resources, since it requires no high notes. Mari-Anne Haggaender was lovely as her sister, Freia, and Alan Held made a good impression as the god Froh. Kaaren Erickson, Diane Kesling and Meredith Parsons were an unusually vivid trio of Rhinemaidens, and Matti Salminen and Jan-Hendrik Rootering made a formidable pair of giants. The Met orchestra, conducted by James Levine, has polished its playing of this work brilliantly over the last three seasons. The performance was recorded by television cameras for broadcast as part of the complete ``Ring Cycle'' on four consecutive nights beginning June 18 over the Public Broadcasting Service. The next installment, ``Die Walkuere,'' will be broadcast over the Texaco radio network on Saturday afternoon, April 7.

DOC.HEAD: 66-year-Old Drive-In Serves Up Slice of History
DOC.TEXT: Decades before McDonald's flaunted its golden arches, a roadside diner that looked like a beached tugboat lured customers with old-fashioned root beer and a new-fangled idea: a drive-up window. Clarence Donley boasts his Maid-Rite Sandwich Shop has ``the world's first and oldest drive-up window,'' although experts on commercial architecture say that claim would be hard to prove. Still, the 66-year-old building is listed on the National Register of Historic Places with such prestigious Springfield monuments as Lincoln's Tomb, the Statehouse and the Executive Mansion. ``In terms of fast-food chains, it is one of the oldest existing restaurants in the country,'' said Michael B. Jackson, an architect with the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency. Drive-up restaurants like Maid-Rite, antecedents of today's major fast-food chains, began popping up across the country in the early 1920s. The Springfield building opened in 1924, Donley said. The shop became part of the Maid-Rite chain, whose claim to fame is a sandwich of crumbled, steamed ground beef and onions, when the chain was founded a couple of years later. Today, about 100 Maid-Rites are scattered across the Midwest, but the Springfield one is the only one still operating out of its original building. The original red and white, wood-framed structure was narrow and shaped like a tugboat. It had three stools at its counter and room for, at most, 13 skinny customers in wood-benched booths. Donley bought the shop 19 years ago and in 1985 expanded the store to almost three times its original size. ``It hasn't lost its historical significance because of the addition,'' Jackson said. ``I think they did a good job of preserving the original form of the building.'' Jackson, who is also a spokesman for the Washington, D.C.-based Society for Commercial Archeology, said the claim that the Maid-Rite drive-up window is the oldest is ``not unreasonable,'' but would be difficult to substantiate. He said the organization's newsletter may carry a notice asking if anyone knows of an older drive-up window. Donley prides himself on not giving in to the whims of the fast-food culture. He still serves the same basic menu of Maid-Rite loose-meat hamburgers, french fries and root beer in a frosty mug. That menu has brought Maid-Rite and Donley an almost cult-like following. ``They come from all over, California, Florida,'' he said. ``They'll come back and ask me to make up a quart of the Maid-Rite meat so they can freeze it and take it home with them.'' Melvin Boyd, 68, and his wife, Bonita, 63, said they had been coming to Maid-Rite for almost 40 years. Their 35-year-old son, Les, said he eats there at least once a week. Mrs. Boyd said the shop's faithful crowd of lunch-time regulars has nothing to do with its historic architecture. ``If this place is a landmark, it's because it makes such great hamburgers,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: April Fools' Day pranksters changed the famed ``Hollywood'' sign to Hallywood _ as in Ha Ha Ha _ but police had the last laugh and put the sign to rights before the morning mists lifted Sunday. Police officer K. Moore said someone used a camouflage parachute ``and twisted it around the first `O' so that it sort of looked like an `A.'' He said officers took the parachute down at about 7:30 a.m. An early fog, combined with the groggy first morning of daylight-saving time, kept most residents from seeing the change. ``I think it was kids, playing a joke on April Fools' Day, said police Sgt. Robert Plassmeyer. The original sign, replaced in 1978 by a steel replica, once read ``Hollywoodland.'' It was erected on Mount Lee in 1923 to advertise a real estate development. Since losing the ``land,'' it has been altered several times: To ``Hollyweed'' by advocates of marijuana legalization; ``Ollywood,'' a cover-up reference to Oliver North and the Iran-Contra affair; ``Holywood'' during a Los Angeles visit of Pope John Paul II; and ``Caltech'' by students from the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, custodian of the sign, has expressed concern in the past over pranksters scaling a chain-link fence and clambering over the sign's 55-foot-high letters. The chamber will alter the sign temporarily for a price. Fox Broadcasting Co. paid a reported $27,000 to add lights and the word ``Fox'' to make the sign read ``Fox Hollywood'' for one week in 1987.

You say you're stressed out, fed up and just want to scream? You say you're stuck on that gerbil wheel of life and don't know how to get off? It may be time to join the Lighten Up Club. For $5 you can join the Boston-based club and get a ``Bold Card'' (which reads ``we're all No. 1 and we never expire,'') five spare ``cents of humor,'' the club logo button (nose, glasses and fake arrow), a newsletter and support. The club, with more than 1,000 members in the United States and abroad, was started by a workplace consultant two years ago on April Fool's Day to help people reduce stress through humor. Kathy Rolfe, 44, formed the club after holding a succession of jobs involving stress training, after observing legions of unhappy, anxiety-ridden people made miserable by their jobs. ``I remind them work is not what it's all about,'' said Rolfe. ``I tell them they can have your body but they can't have your mind. I try and give people back control of their happiness.''

A 10-year-old boy has won his battle to keep the American flag flying. Shayne Wooten had been ordered by the new manager of his apartment complex to take down a 3-by-5 flag that flew outside his bedroom window. The flag, a gift from his grandfather, had been there for a year. On Friday, the president of the Dallas company that owns the Windsor complex said the manager misunderstood the rule banning signs and banners and the prohibition wasn't meant to include the American flag. Pat Holder, president of Lexford Properties, said Shayne can keep the flag flying. ``My hat's off to him,'' said Holder, an ex-Marine who said he flies the American flag outside his own office. Shayne's mother, Sharon Curry, said her son called the commander of a local Veterans of Foreign Wars post for help. He encouraged Shayne to refuse to take down the flag.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Offers to Meet With de Klerk; Indicates Division in ANC
LaserPhoto PMB1
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela on Sunday offered to meet with President F.W. de Klerk to discuss how to end violence, but said police conduct will determine when the African National Congress decides to talk with the government. Mandela indicated to reporters that he is having differences with fellow leaders within his anti-apartheid organization, though he refused to discuss it publicly. Authorities said eight more people died in the past 24 hours during black factional fighting and clashes between protesters and police in Natal province. Addressing an estimated 300,000 people in this southern black township outside Port Elizabeth, the acting leader of the ANC appealed to whites to condemn police shootings of black demonstrators. ``Whites here have become used to police shootings of black demonstrators,'' Mandela said. He defended the ANC decision to cancel April 11 talks with the government in protest of a clash last Monday between police and protesters that killed more than 10 blacks and injured 400 in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg. ``Depending on the response of police,'' the ANC and the government could work out a new date for formal talks, he said. ``The actions of the police against peaceful protest in various parts of the country are in direct conflict with the public positions being taken by the government.'' Mandela was nearly crushed by black people surging forward to touch him, as marshals fought to push him to the speaker's platform on an open field in the township. De Klerk has said he is studying a report on the shootings in Sebokeng but that in the meantime, talks should be held on avoiding further violence. He said he had told Mandela: ``my door remained open and he was welcome to meet with me.'' At a news conference after the rally, Mandela said he is willing to meet with de Klerk to discuss the violence but gave no specific time. He indicated it would follow his visit Monday and Tuesday to southeastern Natal province, where five years of black factional fighting has intensified in the past week, causing scores of deaths and hundreds of injuries. Mandela also said he hoped, during his two-day trip, to meet with Mangosuthu Buthelezi, although he was persuaded by Natal ANC officials to cancel a Monday a joint peace rally he had suggested holding with the Zulu homeland leader. The ANC executive in Lusaka, Zambia announced Saturday it canceled the meeting Mandela and an ANC delegation were to have held with the president on April 11. The discussion was to have focused on obstacles to negotiations about an end to white minority rule. During Sunday's news conference, Mandela was questioned repeatedly about two cancellations in two days of his initiatives. He would not talk about specifics, or explain what the cancellations meant to his position as deputy president of the ANC. But he acknowledged that he had differences of opinions with other ANC leaders. ``I do not intend discussing any differences among black leaders,'' he said. ``But I prefer addressing the question to the particular person involved and not through making use of the public media for settling disputes.'' Mandela, released from 27 years imprisonment on Feb. 11, is the effective head of the ANC while President Oliver Tambo recovers in Sweden from a stroke. But events of the past two days suggest he may not have the freedom to pursue initiatives without approval of younger, more militant ANC leaders. Differences of opinion and lack of coordination among the internal and exile leaders have also increased since the organization was legalized Feb. 2. Sometimes leaders deny events have occurred or insist that statements haven't been made after journalists have witnessed and reported them. Some officials issue statements on behalf of the ANC, but refuse to identify themselves or say who has authorized the statement.

DOC.HEAD: Man Uses Bogus Check To Buy Rolls-Royce
DOC.TEXT: A smooth-talking man in a cashmere coat took an auto dealer for a $38,000 ride, using a bogus cashier's check to buy a Rolls-Royce, authorities said. Dave Remer of Modern Classics Inc., said he had a ``gut feeling something was amiss'' before he gave away the keys to the 1979 tan Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith. But he gave them away anyhow. Police are seeking a man they identify as Frank Adrian Lewis, 34. He was picked up by police on a traffic violation shortly after the car was ``sold'' but was released a few hours later. Two weeks ago, Remer said, a man believed to be Lewis showed up and started tossing around his knowledge of Rolls-Royces. He looked like a Rolls customer, wearing a cashmere topcoat and dark blue suit. His voice had an air of educated authority. The deal was struck and Remer accepted a cashier's check that apparently was cut for $10 and altered by high-quality photocopy machines. Remer said he delivered the Rolls after Lewis told him his wife's Ferrari was in the shop and friends couldn't give him a lift to the dealership because they had lost the keys to their Mercedes. Police say Lewis was pulled over for a traffic violation about an hour later and jailed when police learned he was driving with a suspended license. Later that night, he was released and reclaimed the Rolls. ``He's still got it, but he ain't that good,'' said fraud detective Pat Kelley, who believes the car will be spotted sooner or later. Police in Federal Way, Wash., are working a case where the identical check number was used in a fraud there, Kelley said.

DOC.HEAD: Lance Missile Problem for NATO
Ed: Final 4 grafs EMBARGOED for 6:30 p.m. EDT use
DOC.TEXT: The United States is considering ``bold, imaginative'' proposals to deal with controversial NATO plans for a new short-range nuclear missile in Europe, a senior administration official said. The idea of updating the Lance missile _ which would be based on West German soil and used to halt a Soviet thrust through central Europe _ has run into trouble in Congress. It also has encountered fierce public opposition in West Germany in light of moves toward democracy in Poland and Hungary, and by the prospects for German reunification. A NATO meeting last spring in Brussels nearly collapsed over the issue, when U.S. and British officials pressed for the modernization of the Lance but ran into stiff opposition from West German and other alliance members. In the end, the alliance smoothed over the matter by agreeing to postpone a decision on deploying the missile until 1992. But the surge of change in Europe _ and pressure in Congress for slashing the U.S. military budget _ is forcing open the debate once again. In his 1991 Pentagon budget, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has asked Congress for $112.2 million to develop a new short-range missile as a replacement for the aging, ground-based Lance currently deployed throughout Europe. Faced with the prospect of a balky Congress and another intra-alliance showdown over the issue at the annual spring session of NATO's Nuclear Planning Group, officials on both sides of the Atlantic are working on alternative ideas, said the U.S. official, who spoke Friday on condition of anonymity. The official declined to elaborate, nor would he answer directly when asked whether U.S. officials were contemplating dropping the idea of moving ahead with the Lance modernization. But he said a host of informal ideas are being studied. He emphasized that no formal administration decisions have been made on the missile issue. ``Cables are flying all around,'' the official said. ``We're looking for bold, imaginative proposals to present at the NPG (Nuclear Planning Group.)'' The session is informally scheduled for next month. The official pointed out that it is an alliance matter that must be dealt with within the framework of negotiations inside the NATO partnership. ``We don't have anything hard and fast yet,'' the official said. ``But it's clear that the alliance isn't sitting on its hands,'' he added. ``We know that the world has changed.'' In an interview earlier this month with the publication Defense News, Gen. Colin Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said he had not discussed alternative Lance deployments, such as basing unassembled missiles in Britain. The Lance issue opens a Pandora's box of questions, since it is not the alliance's only short-range nuclear missile. Such missiles have not been included in any superpower arms control negotiations, but the West Germans would like to see them introduced into the process. Formally, the alliance has said it will not enter into such talks until after the East-West conventional force reduction talks are implemented. The alliance's military strategy is based on the concept of ``flexible response'' _ the idea that it must have a land-based nuclear capability to respond to a Soviet assault. The removal of the intermediate-range nuclear missiles under the INF U.S.-Soviet missile accord left the short-range nuclear weapons as the major land-based system. There are 88 Lance missile launchers in Europe, each with a range of less than 100 miles. The updated version of the weapon would be able to reach targets up to 280 miles away. Most of the 88 launchers and their 700 warheads are based on West German soil. But U.S. military officials have warned recently that despite the changes that have swept the Warsaw Pact, they've seen little reduction in its stockpile of tactical nuclear weapons.
DOC.HEAD: The following is EMBARGOED for use at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A panel of congressional leaders, scholars, former government officials and retired military officers has suggested the administration's $112.2 million request for the Lance program ``would be better spent elsewhere.'' In a report sponsored by the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute, the group said the U.S. nuclear guarantee and the presence of a ``substantial number'' of U.S. troops in Europe will continue to serve U.S. interests ``for years to come.'' The study, put forward to a group of defense writers by Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, and former Defense Secretary Harold Brown, said, however, that the ``mission, number and structure of short-range nuclear forces should be reviewed prior to the opening of talks on these weapons. ``In view of U.S. budgetary constraints and West Germany's firm opposition to deploying new short-range, nuclear-armed missiles, the group concludes that funds requested in the fiscal 1991 budget for the Lance modernization program would be better spent elsewhere,'' a statement by the group said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Joins Washington Press Corps' Annual Satirical Romp

DOC.TEXT: The Gridiron Club served up broccoli, satire and song in the press corps' annual spring skewering of President Bush and droves of the capital's mightiest politicos. It was, as Gridiron President David S. Broder of The Washington Post put it at Saturday's skit, ``the night of the long butter-knives.'' The reporters-turned-song-and-dance-persons inflicted a few of the cuts on themselves, singing: ``We're journalists of ``Seniority ``There aren't many hacks ``As important as we...'' But mostly they aimed their banter and bile at figures who marched across the world stage in the past 12 months, from the president to Manuel Noriega to Mikhail Gorbachev. It was the 105th annual installment of the Gridiron dinner. Every president since Benjamin Harrison in 1892 has attended at least one. Barbara Bush didn't turn up in a henna-haired wig, as she did in reality at last year's show, but the first lady did get to hear a skit in which a Barbara Bush character sang: ``The man that I married can sometimes be ``A little too far to the right of me. ... ``If George spoke with your voice, ``His lips would read pro-choice -- ``Like mine.'' The more than 600 guests at the white-tie dinner found sprigs of broccoli alongside the buffalo steaks on their plates _ a culinary poke at the president's recent refusal to eat the leafy vegetable. If anyone missed the point, a journalist posing as a 7-foot stalk of broccoli was led on stage by a chef shouting, ``Room service for President Bush!'' Bush, in an end-of-the-show turn on stage, poked fun at his own gullibility in taking a phony call from someone pretending to be the president of Iran. ``I never thought I'd hear from Elvis again,'' Bush said to laughter from the audience. Bush also gave a vintage sample of the clipped, pronoun-less Bushisms that comedians love to mimic. ``San Francisco earthquake. Not my fault,'' Bush said. ``San Andreas fault.'' The show also saluted East European democracy and skewered Democrats' foibles from Congress to City Hall. Clarabelle Clown cavorted on stage and Howdy Doody (alias House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt) sang: ``It's Richard Gephardt time, ``It's goody two-shoes time. ... ``If honesty won't fly, ``Then we will learn to lie!'' The stage Democrats hired ``Roger Ailment,'' a parody of Bush campaign consultant Roger Ailes, to teach them to ``play rough, like Republicans do.'' Pundits posing as Bill Bradley, Mario Cuomo, Al Gore and Jesse Jackson sang: ``We won't run _ don't make us... ``We shan't run _ we're bound to fail. ``We'd rather wait and run against Danny Quayle.'' To the strains of ``They All Laughed,'' former president Jimmy Crter and Nicaraguan President-elect Violetta Chamorro did a duet with the refrain, ``Peanut Man, we've got the last laugh now.'' And on a local note in this capital where Mayor Marion Barry is under indictment for cocaine possession, two actresses posing as hizzoner's ex-companions Karen Johnson and Rasheeda Moore sang: ``Our boyfriend's back ... ``Hey, la, de, la, His Honor's back. ... ``Hey, you tried to put him down. ``Yah, but he still runs this town.'' On the international front, the Manuel Noriega character sang: ``I'm a Yankqui Doodle Dandy, ``A vet'ran of the CIA, ``A covert nephew of our Uncle Sam. ``How can you treat me this way? ... ``Why'd you have to send your army, ``And those damn boom boxes? ``What happened to the good old times?'' Later, in a reference to the recent opening of a McDonald's fast-food restaurant in Moscow, a Gorbachev stand-in sang: ``You deserve a break today! ``Eat Beeg Mac and plastic tray! ``At MacGorby's!'' A couple masquerading as Ronald and Nancy Reagan crooned ``Easy Street'' about the ex-president's recent $2 million speaking gig in Tokyo: ``Easy Street! Can't be beat. ``Lux-ur-ee is our song.'' Initiated into the club of 60 leading Washington journalists Saturday night were Thomas J. Brazaitis of The Plain Dealer of Cleveland, Anne L. Groer of The Orlando Sentinel, Cragg Hines of the Houston Chronicle, Frank Jackman of the Daily News of New York, Charles J. Lewis of Hearst Newspapers, Kathy Lewis of The Houston Post and Ronald J. Ostrow of the Los Angeles Times. AP Vice President Walter R. Mears was the music chairman of the show, with Richard T. Cooper of the Los Angeles Times and Susan Page of Newsday the skit producers.

DOC.HEAD: Modrow: East Germans Afraid of Being Sold Out During Unification
DOC.TEXT: East Germans are becoming restless with worry that they will be plunged into poverty when their nation is unified with West Germany, the country's outgoing Communist premier said in an interview published Sunday. Hans Modrow, who stands to lose his job in the coming weeks when a new government takes office, said West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is backing away from promises to East German voters that their money would be worth the same as West German marks. Modrow said Kohl was able to influence the outcome of the East German elections by promising prosperity to East German voters if they elected candidates who favor the chancellor's plan for quick unification. ``Inevitably a situation has therefore developed which contradicts all that Chancellor Kohl repeatedly said during the election campaign,'' Modrow was quoted as saying by the West German Bild newspaper. Modrow told the paper that East Germans are ``becoming increasingly upset'' that they will be short-changed by the monetary merger. He said Kohl should bear responisibility for any strikes or demonstrations. Some believe the debate over the conversion rate could affect the outcome of West Germany's general election later this year and determine how many more East Germans flee their country for the West. East Germans reacted with alarm this weekend after the West German central bank announced it was proposing an exchange rate of two East German marks for one West German mark as part of a plan to merge the nations' currencies. Following a meeting between the East German Christian Democrat chairman, Lothar de Maiziere, and Social Democrat deputy chief, Markus Merkel, both men said they rejected the proposed 2-1 monetary union rate. ``Our goal is a money exchange of 1-1,'' de Maiziere told reporters. ``I see no clear or understandable reason to change that position.'' Merkel said the Social Democrats reject the 2-1 proposed rate as ``totally unacceptable.'' Meanwhile, the head of East Germany's Labor Union Federation, Helga Mausch, told the official news agency ADN that the organization was urging its 8.6 million members ``to fight for their rights and demonstrate next week,'' against the proposed exchange rate. East Germans, who have amassed large savings because of a shortage of consumer goods under the Communists, were hoping for a 1-1 conversion, based on election campaign speeches made by Kohl and other conservatives. Kohl said Saturday he never promised an equal exchange of East German marks for West German marks, but Modrow said Kohl did. ``He promised it again and again,'' Bild quoted Modrow as saying. ``The voters clearly saw it that way. The outcome of the election was as a result of those promises.'' East Germans voting in their first free elections on March 18 overwhelmingly chose a Christian Democrat-led, conservative alliance that Kohl helped organized. Kohl made regular trips to the East to campaign for the coalition. The Christian Democrats continued to negotiate Sunday with the second-place finisher in the election, the left-leaning Social Democrats, on forming a coalition that would dominate East Germany's new 400-member Parliament. Modrow leads the overhauled Communist Party that embraced a form of democratic socialism after the old Stalinist regime was overthrown during last year's mass demonstrations. The Communists finished a distant third in the elections. The new Parliament is expected to convene for the first time this week. Under the exchange rate established by the former Communist regime, three East German marks bought one West German mark. The East German mark is non-convertible, however, and has virtually no value in Western markets. Karl Otto Poehl, the chairman of West Germany's Bundesbank, said Saturday the state bank's plan for a 2-1 conversion actually raises the value of the East German mark. Small savings accounts of up to 2,000 marks ($1,175) still would be exchanged at a 1-1 rate, Poehl said. Kohl's government, facing elections in December, is trying to walk a fine line between living up to election promises to East German voters without placing too great an economic burden on West German voters. East Germany's collapsing economy and the nearly 500,000 East Germans who fled to the West since January 1989, were main factors in the revolt that ousted the old Communist regime. Some officials, including Ulf Fink of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union, have predicted that anything less than a 1-1 conversion could cause a new exodus of East Germans to the West. ``Another exodus would be more costly than a general 1-1 rate for all savings,'' Fink was quoted by the Neue Osnabreucker Zeitung as saying. West German financial experts say it will cost hundreds of billions of marks to improve obsolete industries and repair roads and communications in East Germany. Much of that burden is expected to affect the wealthy West German economy, possibly resulting in rising inflation, a decline in the value of the powerful West mark and perhaps new taxes. Proponents of a 1-1 conversion say it is necessary to allow East German workers and elderly people living off savings accounts to maintain adequate living standards in a unified Germany. East Germans currently depend on heavy government subsidies for housing, food and employment. The subsidies will be quickly phased out in the new free-market economy when unification comes.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Violence Reports
With AM-Bus Driver Shot, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are major incidents of violence recorded by Greyhound Lines Inc. since the bus drivers strike began March 2, according to company attorney Melanie Scofield and other reports. The company has reported at least 70 bomb threats, 29 shootings and numerous other incidents of threat or vandalism, such as vacant buses set on fire. The union denies a role in the violence and cites at least 60 violent incidents by replacement drivers against strikers. One striker, Robert Waterhouse, was killed March 3 on a Redding, Calif., picket line when he was crushed by a bus driven by a replacement. But the driver was not charged. Here are the major attacks on buses listed by Greyhound: March 2 _ Two shots fired into Greyhound's main Chicago terminal. No injuries. March 3 _ Driver reports hearing a loud noise like an explosion about a mile northeast of Wytheville, Va. An inspection of the vehicle reveals a bullet hole in the lower left corner of the windshield. No injuries. March 3 _ Shot fired at bus as it leaves another bus station in Chicago. Two people slightly injured by flying debris. March 3 _ A bus en route to Cleveland is fired on at a toll gate in Indiana. The shot penetrates a radiator screen on the back of the bus. No injuries. March 9 _ Three shots fired at a bus carrying 29 passengers from Cleveland to Louisville, Ky., on Interstate 71 between Columbus, Ohio, and Cincinnati. Passengers transfer to another bus and continue on to Cincinnati. March 9 _ A driver en route from Phoenix to Los Angeles hears a ``pop'' and finds a bullet hole in the door of the bus. The driver says a car in front of the bus begins flashing its lights moments before the shooting. No injuries. March 11 _ Shot hits a bus traveling from Detroit to St. Petersburg, Fla., about 12 miles south of Jacksonville, Fla., injuring eight people. March 12 _ A bus traveling from New York to Boston via Hartford, Conn., is shot at as it travels on Interstate 84. A single bullet penetrated the middle hatch of the baggage bin. No injuries. March 12 _ A Greyhound-owned Trailways bus parked in a storage yard in Fresno, Calif., is set on fire with a road flare. No injuries. March 13 _ A sniper opens fire on a moving Greyhound bus in Chicago, hitting the door with one bullet and a front window with another. No injuries. Passengers are transferred to another bus bound for Memphis, Tenn. March 14 _ Two shots strike a window of a Greyhound bus carrying 48 passengers traveling outside Chattanooga, Tenn. No injuries. March 18 _ A bus was fired on in downtown Cleveland. No injuries. March 19 _ Glass shattered in front door of Tallahassee, Fla., terminal by pellet or BB. March 20 _ Two shots hit driver's front window, and one hits passenger front window while bus with 50 passengers passes through Roanoke, Va., en route to Christianburg terminal. No injuries. March 21 _ A single shot strikes the right passenger door of a bus carrying 30 passengers in San Antonio. No injuries. March 21 _ A bus is pelted by rocks while traveling near Las Vegas. An elderly passenger was slightly injured by flying glass. March 22 _ In St. Louis, Mo, three shots strike at the driver's window of a bus carrying 19 passengers. No injuries. March 22 _ Four shots fired at bus carrying eight passengers in Collinsville, Ill. Two hit driver's front window; two more hit left side of bus. No injuries. March 22 _ Bus fired upon 15 miles east of Lake Charles, La. The bullet penetrated a rear air filter. No passengers were aboard. March 23 _ A bus carrying 59 passengers in Cleveland is fired upon with bow and arrow. No injuries. March 26 _ A shot was fired at a crowded Greyhound bus terminal in Amarillo, Texas. No injuries. March 26 _ A bullet destroys the right-hand mirror of a bus carrying 32 passengers near Orlando, Fla. No injuries. March 29 _ A bus carrying 26 passengers is fired upon near Tulsa, Okla. No injuries. March 30 _ A bus driver arriving in Harrisburg, Pa., from Pittsburgh, discovers a bullet had struck the bus near the baggage compartment. No injuries. March 31 _ The driver of a bus traveling from Nashville, Tenn., to Louisville, Ky., is shot by a man in a passing pickup on a highway near White House, Tenn. The driver is critically wounded. No passengers are injured. The bus belongs to Southeastern Trailways, an independent company, but operates on a Greyhound route with Greyhound passengers under a pooling arrangement.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Dies When Small Airplane Hits Broadcast Tower
DOC.TEXT: A single-engine plane struck a 300-foot broadcast tower atop a fog-bound mountain and crashed Sunday, killing the pilot, state police said. The pilot was the only one aboard the Cessna, which crashed shortly before noon on Illinois Mountain in the town of Highland, about 50 miles north of New York City, according to state police reports. The pilot's name was not released and plane's origin and destination were unknown, state police said. Witnesses said the eastbound plane was about 40 feet above tree level when it hit the tower owned by Five States Tower Co. The crash did not disrupt broadcasting, said Jerry Lademan of WEOK in Poughkeepsie, one of several stations that use the tower. The plane hit 130 feet up on the 300-foot tower, Lademan said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher, Kinnock Blame Extremists For Anti-Tax Protest That Turned Into Riot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with new scuffle, 86 citizens hospitalized. Pickup 9th graf `Detective Chief...'; INSERTS graf after 21st graf `The new...' to ADD earlier Glasgow protest. Pickup 22nd graf `Critics have...'; EDITS to trim.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and opposition politicians on Sunday blamed extremist groups for turning a carnival-like anti-tax protest in Trafalgar Square into one of London's worst riots this century. On Sunday, about 100 protesters chanting ``No poll tax!'' and ``Can't pay, won't pay!'' clashed with police for a second day when Home Secretary David Waddington toured the scene of Saturday's riot. Four people were arrested. A protest by 40,000 people against a new local tax turned violent Saturday when thousands of militants smashed windows, set cars ablaze and battled police for several hours. Hundreds of people were injured and hundreds were arrested. The so-called community charge, which took effect Sunday in England and Wales, replaces a property tax with a levy on each adult and increases the amount many pay by up to a third. Critics say it's unfair because Britain's richest man, the Duke of Westminster, pays the same rate as his gardener. Ms. Thatcher told reporters of her ``absolute horror'' at Saturday's violence. ``People have a right to demonstrate peacefully. This was taken over by some extreme groups who used violence with no consideration for others or their property,'' she said near her country residence in Chequers. Labor Party chief Neil Kinnock, whose party is 28 points ahead of Mrs. Thatcher's Conservatives, said those who caused the violence must be ``treated as criminals'' and punished. Scotland Yard launched a top-level investigation into the six-hour street battle which sent 58 police and 86 civilians to the hospital, injured 22 police horses and caused hundreds of thousands of dollars of damage. Detective Chief Supt. Roy Ramm, leading the investigation, said 341 people had been arrested for offenses including arson, robbery, serious assault, criminal damage and looting. The heart of London looked like a war zone after a battle on Sunday. Clean-up crews cleared rubble and burned-out cars from the streets and strollers wandered past boarded-up restaurants, pubs and shops whose windows had been smashed. Many victims were among Britain's most exclusive names: Liberty's, Burberrys, Mappin and Webb, Dickens and Jones. In Trafalgar Square, a pall of black smoke was still rising from construction cabins on the side of a seven-story building undergoing renovation which had been set on fire by the protesters. The South African Embassy across the street had smashed windows and one window area blackened by a firebomb that missed setting the building ablaze. ``We are supposed to be the violent ones, in the U.S.A.,'' said tourist Harold Eaton of St. Louis, surveying the scene. ``I am surprised that something like this could happen in what is such a civilized place.'' The Independent on Sunday newspaper called it the worst riot in central London this century. Scotland Yard said it was one of the worst but nobody had yet researched whether it was the worst. Chief Inspector Graham Bartlett, a 24-year police veteran who was kicked in the eye and hit on the head when he went to rescue a man who had been knocked out, said it was ``the most severe'' attack on police he had ever seen, worse than the 1981 Brixton riot in south London. David Meynell, Scotland Yard's deputy assistant commissioner, blamed the ``sustained and savage violence'' on about 3,500 people who were among a crowd of 40,000 at a rally in Trafalgar Square. Organizers put the crowd at 200,000. ``I thought yesterday you saw a patch of anarchy coming to London,'' Meynell told a news conference. ``Certainly there were some anarchists there and other extreme elements.'' Meynell said the clashes began when some demonstrators heading up Whitehall to Trafalgar Square stopped at the corner of Downing Street, where Mrs. Thatcher has her official residence, and tried to storm the barricaded entrance to the street. Of those injured, he said, only two police officers and two civilians remained hospitalized Sunday. Steve Nally of the All-Britain Anti-Poll Tax Federation, which organized the rally, said on Sky Television News that police overreacted to provocation by a small number of demonstrators at Downing Street. The new tax is part of Mrs. Thatcher's crusade to bury British socialism by hitting at its last bastion _ local government. The levy, which went into effect in Scotland a year ago, has been greeted with frequent demonstrations, some violent. The ugly scenes in London overshadowed a huge, peaceful demonstration Saturday in Glasgow, Scotland, where at least 20,000 people protested the tax. Critics have dubbed it the poll tax after a per-capita tax that set off a peasants' revolt in 1381. Many councils _ Conservative as well as Labor _ have set charges far higher than the government's estimate of $450, claiming the government failed to consider that inflation would rise above 8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Join Forces to Knock Down Anti-Inflation Plan
DOC.TEXT: Brazilian political parties are joining forces to knock down key provisions of President Fernando Collor de Mello's drastic economic austerity plan, on which Congress begins voting Monday. In the first serious hurdle to Collor's 2-week-old administration, Congress will grapple with the 26 measures that have paralyzed Brazil's economy and raised fears of social instability. Lawmakers have two weeks to scrap or alter the plan. Collor, Brazil's first popularly elected leader since 1960, decreed the country's fifth and most radical austerity package March 16 to curb 4,853 percent annual inflation and jump start Brazil's stagnant economy. But the plan _ which freezes savings accounts above $1,200 for 18 months, severely tightens the money supply, raises taxes and utility rates, and slashes government spending _ has run into mounting opposition. Brazil's Communist Party, the leftist Workers Party and the center-left Democratic Labor Party have condemned the package. In addition, five centrist parties holding a solid majority of about 400 votes in the 570-member Congress have demanded substantial changes. Voting is expected Monday and Tuesday on four of the less controversial measures. Voting on the heart of the plan is expected to be held later in the week or early next week. Under pressure from labor unions, businessmen and voters, party leaders have expressed support for increasing the limit of bank withdrawals. The freeze has caused a brutal shortage of currency, causing consumer demand to drop near zero and triggering massive layoffs. Unions estimate that more than 200,000 Brazilians have lost their jobs since the plan was implemented. Hardest hit were construction and auto industry workers, including 19,000 laid off in southern Parana state and 11,000 in Rio de Janeiro. ``We won't disfigure this plan, but there will be corrections,'' said Rep. Marco Maciel of the right-of-center Liberal Front Party. Collor, however, has said the plan is ``nonnegotiable'' and warned he will veto any alterations by Congress. ``The president does not want a confrontation, but he won't allow the plan to be watered down,'' said Rep. Renan Calheiros, leader of Collor's tiny National Reconstruction Party, which holds just 24 congressional seats. Collor can veto any Congressional amendments to his plan, but Congress can overide his veto with a simple majority. Collor's aggressive posture had earned him public support and unofficial backing from Congress, but Brazilians are grumbling increasingly about layoffs and a delay in receiving March wages. Now, even Collor's allies in Congress are pondering whether or not to hedge their bets and soften the package. ``We're receiving an average of 800 angry letters a day from people asking the government to let them take their money out of their savings acounts,'' said Rep. Ibsen Pinheiro of the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, which holds a House majority. ``It has an effect on your vote.'' Collor's wage policy is also under attack. This month, workers received a 73-percent pay raise to cover for March's 84 percent inflation, and they will not be reimbursed for cost-of-living increases in the first two weeks of April. ``Nothing is unnegotiable,'' said Sen. Fernando Henrique Cardoso, of the left-of-center Brazilian Social Democracy Party. ``The untouchable nature of the plan has been revoked.'' But analysts fear any tinkering with the economic measures might undermine Collor's credibility and hurl the economy into chaos. ``Collor has shot his bolts,'' wrote a political commentator, Villas Boas Correa, in the Rio daily Jornal do Brasil. ``The rejection of the package or major changes in it will be unacceptable to Collor and lead to an institutional crisis of massive proportions.''

DOC.HEAD: Belgium's Most Wanted Fugitive Extradited From Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Haemers, Belgium's most-wanted fugitive, was extradited from Brazil on Sunday to face trial for kidnapping a former prime minister and staging 12 holdups in which four people were killed. Haemers, 37, was flown in a Belgian air force C-130 transport plane that made a refueling stop in the Canary Islands. He was arrested in Rio de Janeiro with his wife, French-born Denise Tyack Du Bon, 35, and Belgian Axel Zeyen, 34. They also were extradited. The plane landed at an air force base in Koksijde, 75 miles west of Brussels, and the three were driven to the nation's criminal police headquarters in Brussels. Brazilian authorities kept Haemers' departure date a secret. As a further precaution, guards spirited him out the back door of his prison. Haemers escaped from a police van in 1987 in Brussels and eluded authorities until he was caught in Rio last May. At the time of his escape, he was charged with 12 holdups in which four people were killed and four injured. He also is charged with kidnapping former Prime Minister Paul Vanden Boeynants in Brussels in early 1989. The politician was released unharmed a month after his family paid an undisclosed ransom. No trial dates have been set.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge U.S. Crackdown on Iraq
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 15th graf pvs, bgng: Specifically, Cohen, to RESTORE Bingaman comment
DOC.TEXT: The United States should crack down on Iraq for allegedly trying to circumvent American restrictions on nuclear technology shipments and for using chemical weapons, three senators said Sunday. ``I think ... there should be sound and fury and all we're hearing now is the sounds of silence'' from the Bush administration, said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, the ranking Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee. ``I think we ought to take action, and not simply allow it to be (a) headline one day and then fade off into nothing the next,'' Cohen said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' program. ``I don't think we've done enough,'' Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' McCain said the Iraqis must be forewarned that the United States ``will exercise all options, including that of military, if necessary, to prevent this enormous threat from continuing if they acquire the nuclear weapons we think they are maybe three to four years away from.'' Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, must be stopped on his ``messianic mission'' to become a dominant force in the Middle East, McCain said. U.S. and British intelligence forces broke up an alleged Iraqi smuggling ring in London last week. Officials claimed the Iraqis were trying to obtain U.S.-made nuclear triggers for atomic weapons. Five people were charged in an indictment that claimed an Iraqi government agency was involved in the scheme. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, said his country does not have nuclear capability and denied it was trying to build a nuclear bomb. McCain challenged the Iraqi's denial. ``The facts are the Iraqis have for over a decade been attempting to acquire nuclear capability,'' he said. The Israelis bombed a Iraqi nuclear facility in 1981. Moreover, McCain charged the Iraqis have failed to abide by the nuclear non-proliferation treaty to which they are signatories. Both McCain and Cohen said the Iraqis' statements have to be taken with a grain of salt in light of their denials they used chemical weapons in the Iran-Iraq war and in efforts to put down Kurdish nationalists. ``The Iraqis gassed some 5,000 Kurds back in 1988, thousands more Iranians,'' Cohen said. Congress could do something about the situation, the senators said. Specifically, Cohen cited a proposed law that would penalize American companies doing business with Middle Eastern countries working to acquire chemical weapons and nuclear capabilities. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., also appearing on the ABC program, said ``I think we need to get tough, not just with those Middle Eastern countries, but also with those that are supplying them.'' McCain said Congress might be more willing now than in the past to impose sanctions on such companies. ``I think that finally we're beginning to focus, hopefully with the assistance of the Soviet Union, on the enormity and the immensity of the challenges that this ... presents us with,'' he said. Exposure of the smuggling ring prompted President Bush to express his concern about the spread of nuclear weapons in the Middle East. And the State Department registered its fears with the Iraqi ambassador.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Plans Up to Five New Jewish Enclaves in Occupied Lands
DOC.TEXT: Caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has set in motion plans to quickly start five more Jewish settlements in the occupied territories, an aide said Sunday. The action is bound to fuel tensions with the United States, whose leaders have renewed warnings that the settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip are an obstacle to peace. Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, acted as his political rival, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, sped up efforts to form a new governing coalition without Likud. President Chaim Herzog asked Peres to put together a new coalition after the Likud-Labor Cabinet led by Shamir collapsed March 15 in a parliamentary vote of no confidence triggered by a dispute over Middle East peacemaking. Yossi Ahimeir, a Shamir aide, said of the premier's plans for settlements: ``We are talking about completing the picture of eight settlements decided by our government, and there's no doubt that sooner or later they will be established.'' Israel radio said former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of the left-of-center Labor Party had postponed construction of five of the settlements in response to American protests. The defense minister has final say on when settlements will be built. Ahimeir noted that Shamir was now acting as defense minister, a post he took over after Rabin's resignation from the Cabinet on March 13 during the crisis that led to the government collapse. ``If there were artificial delays until now, they will be removed,'' Ahimeir said in a telephone interview. Ahimeir said the settlements were authorized by a Cabinet decision more than a year ago. Labor legislator Avraham Burg said Shamir also wanted to confiscate additional land for settlements and enlarge the present Jewish enclaves around Hebron, where clashes have occurred between settlers and Palestinians. Burg told The Associated Press that Shamir's plans were in line with the Likud philosphy of not giving up any land in the occupied territories, even in exchange for peace. ``Part of the plan is to kill the peace process,'' he said. Since capturing the West Bank and Gaza during the 1967 Middle East War, Israel has built 143 settlements that are home to 75,000 Jews. About 1.7 million Palestinians live in the occupied lands. An additional 120,000 Israelis have been moved into neighborhoods built in the Israeli-annexed sector of Jerusalem, where 140,000 Palestinians live. Three settlements have been opened since Shamir was re-elected premier in November 1988. These are Ofarim and Tsoref, started May 10 in the West Bank, and Kfar Darom, started about the same time in Gaza. Five others, agreed on as a compromise between Shamir and Peres when they formed their coalition government, have not been built, and their names and sites have not been disclosed. Ahimeir confirmed a radio report that Shamir has named Michael Dekel, a veteran Likud activist and former deputy defense minister, to be in charge of building the new settlements. The radio said Dekel still needs permits from the military government in the occupied teritories and the Justice Ministry, which controls land purchases. In the past, some settlements have been started by putting up fences and moving in mobile homes. Peres, meanwhile, was seeking to break a 60-60 deadlock with Likud to win a majority coalition in the 120-member Parliament, by trying to enlist defectors from Likud, Israeli media reported. By law Peres has about 10 more days to form a government and then can ask Herzog for an extension. This could give Herzog an opportunity to ask Shamir to form a government. Israeli newspapers noted that Rabin, Labor's No. 2 leader, could also be assigned to form a government if Peres fails. Rabin is more popular with religious swing parties, largely because of his tough policies aimed at putting down the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Armored Vehicles Unloaded From Trains, Move Through Vilnius
LaserPhotos VIL1,2,4,5,6, MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of newly arrived Soviet military vehicles lumbered through Lithuania's capital Sunday, but defiant republic leaders resisted the increased pressure to renounce their declaration of independence. The Lithuanian parliament's Presidium met to consider its next moves, and Deputy Prime Minister Kazimieras Motieka told reporters the government ``remains ready to negotiate and discuss any questions with the Soviet Union except that of independence.'' The last Western correspondents were ousted from the Baltic republic Sunday night on orders of the Soviet government, leading some Lithuanians to express fears of an impending crackdown by the Soviet military. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev urged the rebellious republic in an appeal Saturday night to renounce its March 11 declaration of independence and enter into talks with the Kremlin on the basis of the Soviet Constitution. He warned that a refusal may result in ``grave consequences for all of us.'' The Lithuanian parliament was scheduled to meet Monday morning to forge a response. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis rejected Gorbachev's appeal, saying the Soviet leader was demanding ``impossible things.'' ``It cannot be now demanded that we annul everything that we bore in our hearts,'' he said in remarks carried Sunday by the official Soviet news agency Tass. But Landsbergis said he would send negotiators to Moscow on Monday to try to set up a meeting with Soviet officials. Western reporters counted almost 30 armored vehicles being unloaded from trains that arrived near the Vilnius airport. Others drove through the city, their treads slicing into the asphalt, apparently on their way to a nearby base. Soldiers peered out of the lookouts. The reinforcement of the Vilnius garrison came in broad daylight when many residents were out for Sunday strolls to savor the spring sunshine. Motieka complained that the Soviet army had refused to inform the Lithuanian government about its activities. ``This situation must be changed,'' he said, according to William Hough, an American lawyer who attended the news conference. An additional column of some 15 armored personnel carriers had moved through Vilnius in the early morning hours, Lithuanian officials said. A duty officer at the republic's interior ministry said the vehicles rolled into a military base in central Vilnius just three miles from the parliament building. Eduardas Potashinkas, an activist and Lithuanian TV editor, said many concerned residents had called the television station and Lithuanian radio to report troop movements overnight. Western journalists saw 30 to 40 armored personnel carriers, or APCs, full support vehicles and soldiers being unloaded from a train near the airport north of Vilnius at about noon Sunday. ``There was a big transport that came by train. There were a lot of APCs, over 20 of them at least, and also trucks. It looked like they were beginning to unload,'' a local photographer said on condition of anonymity. Later Sunday, 28 APCs, eight trucks, two jeeps and a tanker could still be seen at the station, while other vehicles were driving through the city. Reporters estimated that at least 45 military vehicles had been brought to the city since midnight Sunday. Gorbachev, in his first formal appeal since the Lithuanian crisis began, said the republic's chosen path towards independence was ``ruinous and will only lead to a dead end.'' In an 18-line statement addressed to the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet, Gorbachev charged Lithuanian leaders with taking steps that ``are openly challenging and insulting to the entire (Soviet) Union.'' ``I propose that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet immediately annul the illegal acts it has adopted,'' Gorbachev wrote in his appeal, which was prominently played Sunday on the front pages of major Soviet newspapers. Landsbergis, in separate comments broadcast on Lithuanian radio, said Gorbachev's ``strongly worded appeal to the Lithuanian parliament is extremely surprising'' and contained ``open threats to the safety of the Lithuanian nation.'' The Council of the Federation, a new group of leaders from the Soviet republics formed to advise the president on nationalities issues, directed Gorbachev on Friday to tell Lithuania that it must rescind laws contradicting the Soviet Constitution before talks on secession could begin. The constitution provides a republic with the right to secede from the Soviet Union but offers no mechanism for secession. Gorbachev has promised Lithuania and other independence-minded Soviet republics to establish such a mechanism, but the measure presently before the Soviet legislature gives the Soviet government final authority in such issues. On Friday, nearby Estonia pledged to join Lithuania in its drive to regain independence lost when the three Baltic republics were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 after Moscow occupied them under terms of a secret Hitler-Stalin pact. The third Baltic republic, Latvia, is expected to pursue independence next month.

DOC.HEAD: President Visits Funeral Home to Pay Respects to Slain State Trooper
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, flew by helicopter here Sunday to pay their respects to the family of a Maryland state trooper slain last week while on patrol. The Bushes went inside the Singleton Funeral Home to view the body of Corp. Theodore D. Wolf, 40, a decorated, 16-year veteran of the Maryland State Police force whose killer or killers have not been apprehended. Bush met with the trooper's widow, Virginia, and his three sons, Ted, 16, Greg, 14, and Nick, 12. Reporters were not allowed into the funeral home. The Bushes spent about 10 minutes inside before departing by motorcade back to nearby Baltimore-Washington International Airport, where his Marine One helicopter was waiting to return him to the White House. Wolf was found slumped over the wheel of his patrol vehicle with the lights flashing, reportedly after he had stopped an auto for speeding on Interstate 95 north of Washington, D.C. A stolen car was later found six miles away, abandoned, with Wolf's burned ticket book inside. Bush has called repeatedly for the death penalty for those who kill police officers.

DOC.HEAD: Four Militants Killed in Kashmir, Soldier Reported Slain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jagmohan as one name is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Security forces shot and killed four Moslem militants who ambushed them Sunday in a southern Kashmir town, state officials said. In another attack, extremists reportedly shot to death a paramilitary soldier. At least 24 militants were arrested in the Kashmir valley, where Moslems are leading a growing campaign to secede from Hindu-dominated India, the state officials said on condition of anonymity. The latest killings raised to 243 the number of people killed in the valley since Jan. 20, when state authorities began a crackdown on the Moslem movement. Officials of Gov. Jagmohan's office in Jammu, the winter capital of Jammu-Kashmir state in India's far north, said four militants were shot and killed Sunday in the town of Anantnag after they ambushed a police patrol. Two automatic rifles and some ammunition were found near their bodies, the officials said. In the city of Srinagar, the center of the unrest, militants shot and killed a paramilitary soldier in a crowded suburb, the United News of India news agency said. The militant campaign in Kashmir originally began in 1947, when the British-ruled subcontinent was split into India and mainly Moslem Pakistan and the ruler of the former princely state of Kashmir chose union with India. Kashmir is dominated by Moslems, however, and the militant campaign has flared over the years. They originally sought union with Pakistan, but they have recently been demanding independence with neutrality. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state's 6 million people. Nationwide, Moslems comprise 12 percent of India's 880 million people, and Hindus make up 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer's Bizarre Murder Trial Nears End
DOC.TEXT: A police officer who was consumed with hatred every time he looked out his window and saw his next-door neighbor eventually shot him to death to settle a 13-year grudge, prosecutors say. Defense lawyers in the trial of Robert McLaughlin contend that the 18-year Hampton police veteran was insane _ a ``zombie'' _ two years ago when he walked around to Robert Cushing's house and opened up with two shotgun blasts when he answered the door. But prosecutors in the 4-week-old murder trial say McLaughlin, 49, is a cold-blooded killer who was angry at Cushing over an old police-brutality charge. The case could go to the jury by the middle of the week. Cushing, a 63-year-old former schoolteacher and prominent real estate agent, was killed by two shotgun blasts after opening his front door in Hampton the night of June 1, 1988. The slaying shocked residents and for nearly three months, police had no solid leads. Then, McLaughlin, an 18-year veteran Hampton police veteran, turned himself in, saying he pulled the trigger. The surrender stunned the community, particularly Cushing's family. ``When we were out in the back yard grieving, mourning the loss of our father, he could see us out his windows,'' Robert Cushing Jr. said at the time. ``It's sick to think the murderer was watching us from his windows. It's like voyeurism on our grief.'' But there was more stunning news to come. A year ago, McLaughlin's former wife, Susan Cook, was convicted of being an accomplice to the murder and given a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole. She is appealing. The next month, during pretrial hearings, McLaughlin startled onlookers by testifying that Cook actually had killed Cushing. Later, shortly before his trial was to begin, McLaughlin's lawyers produced letters written by Cook to McLaughlin from her jail cell. In them, she said she killed Cushing. ``Babe, I pray they find you innocent; they've got to,'' said one letter. ``You didn't kill Mr. Cushing, I did, and I know you said you'd never tell and you'd protect me.'' Shortly after the letters were made public, McLaughlin's lawyers dropped out of the case without explanation and the trial was delayed until new lawyers could be found. Cook continued to write to him for a time, signing her letters, ``All my love.'' Then, inexplicably, she filed for divorce and obtained one earlier this year. McLaughlin's trial opened on March 5 in Rockingham County Superior Court. Prosecutors claim that, with Cook's help, the defendant planned and carried out the murder to settle a long-simmering grudge. ``The initial resentment grew into an ugly hatred,'' Assistant Attorney General Michael Ramsdell said in opening arguments. ``Robert McLaughlin hated (Cushing) every time he looked out his window and saw him working in his garden or sitting on his back deck. He released that hatred on June 1, 1988.'' The grudge, prosecutors say, began when McLaughlin and another officer investigated a traffic accident outside Cushing's home in which an elderly woman driver was cited for driving violations. Cushing, who had been an onlooker, was arrested on a disorderly conduct charge. The driver, who has since died, claimed she was arrested because she had told Cushing she would testify on his behalf. At her trial, she accused McLaughlin and another officer of brutality, saying they ripped her raincoat while trying to pull her out of her car. A group of residents, led by Cushing's son, pushed to have both officers fired on brutality charges, but both were eventually cleared. Defense attorney Steven Shadallah told the jury that McLaughlin ``should not be held criminally responsible for what happened. The killing was a product of delusional thinking in a man who was out of touch with reality.'' Shadallah argued that the night of the killing, McLaughlin, under severe stress from his job, drank heavily, took a heavy dose of tranquilizers and watched ``Apocalypse Now,'' a violent Vietnam War movie _ a combination that induced him to commit the murder. He said Cook helped McLaughlin plan the slaying after he stated his intention to kill his neighbor. ``She is the one who suggested wearing disguises ... using a getaway car ... to serve as a lookout. She directed him to the front door,'' he said. ``He didn't even know to run after the killing; his wife had to tell him. ``This man was a zombie on June 1, 1988.'' Hampton Police Chief Robert Mark, called as a defense witness last week, remembered McLaughlin as a ``cop's cop.'' But Mark and other witnesses said McLaughlin suffered from severe stress that caused him to attempt suicide on one occasion. Shadallah said several traumatic experiences contributed to the stress, including McLaughlin's accidental shooting of one of his best friends at age 15.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Devalues Currency 6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Nicaragua devalued its currency by 6 percent and raised gasoline prices by 11.8 percent on Sunday, the government announced. The new rate of exchange for government and official transactions is 47,000 cordobas per dollar. The official exchange rate had been 44,170 cordobas per dollar since Jan. 21, when the cordoba was last devalued. Sunday's devaluation was the sixth this year. The black market rate, which is illegal but widely tolerated, has reached 120,000 cordobas per dollar. Nicaragua began a tough anti-inflation program last year that includes frequent devaluations to keep prices of exports low and imports expensive. Gasoline prices increased from 77,400 cordobas to 86,500 cordobas a gallon, or the equivalent of $1.84 a gallon. On Feb. 25, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro defeated President Daniel Ortega in Nicaragua's presidential elections. Chamorro's opposition coalition trounced the Sandinistas, in large part because of dissatisfaction with high inflation and unemployment. The government routinely raises gasoline prices along with devaluations because the Central American country is dependent on fuel imports and must pay scarce dollars for supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Hartford's First Skyscraper Comes Tumbling Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 9th graf pvs, `The tower...', to add background on how parts of old building would be used. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Preservationists have...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HF2
DOC.TEXT: In just a matter of seconds Sunday, the city's first skyscraper disintegrated in a flash of flame, a loud rumble and a billowing tidal wave of smoke and dust. The 11-story Hartford-Aetna Building, its metal skeletal innards laced with explosive charges, crashed into a heap of twisted steel girders and dusty concrete chunks at 7 a.m., to the applause of hundreds of spectators. Despite the efforts of preservationists who fought to save the building, the 78-year-old building was knocked down to make way for a 45-story office tower. The demolition went off like clockwork. A man's voice boomed ``five seconds'' over a loudspeaker and precisely five seconds later the blast, with a resonating rumble that shook the ground, brought the building down. The building was brought down by implosion, in which explosives are carefully spaced to ``pull'' a building in on itself to keep debris from flying off the demolition site. Spectators, some crammed onto a pedestrian walkway, others perched on cars or in side streets blocked off by police, oohed, ahhed and applauded as the building fell in spewed a cloud of dust that swept over the downtown area. The demolition ended the debate between the Society for Savings, which plans to erect the new office tower, and preservationists who had argued that the city's first skyscraper should be saved. The Hartford-Aetna, on the corner of Asylum and Main Streets, was the sixth of 11 buildings razed to create the site for the proposed tower. The tower was approved in August, but the city council stipulated that architecturally significant materials from the bottom two floors would be incorporated into the lower floors of the new building. As proposed, the old materials would form the facade on the first two stories of the building's fronts on Main and Asylum streets. Preservationists have ridiculed the project. Michael Kerski, executive director of the Greater Hartford Architecture Conservancy, scoffed at the plan to preserve the old building's first two floors. ``How do you blow something up and then piece it back together?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Attend Communion Service
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Adds graf with later activities
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, attended a communion service Sunday at St. John's Church across Lafayette Park from the White House. They were joined at the 8 a.m. Episcopal service by Bush's sister, Nancy Ellis, and four dozen other worshippers. They heard a short sermon about John 11:18-44, the story of Lazarus, by Susan Keller, a parish intern. Bush often attends services at St. John's when he is at the White House on Sundays. He usually spends weekends at Camp David, Md., where he attends a military chapel. The Bushes stayed home this weekend to attend Saturday night's Gridiron Club dinner, an annual affair held by the Washington press corps. The Bushes later Sunday attended a private party at the home of journalist Charles Bartlett and flew by helicopter to a Glen Burnie, Md., funeral home to pay their respects to the family of a Maryland trooper slain while on patrol last Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Ambush Two Patrols, Kill Six Policemen
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas ambushed a police patrol in a northern town with a dynamite explosion, killing five officers and wounding 11, a newspaper reported Sunday. In another attack northeast of the capital, El Tiempo newspaper reported that one officer was killed and four were wounded. The newspaper said both attacks occurred Saturday. Officials were not available Sunday to confirm them, but such reports by the newspaper generally been reliable in the past. The newspaper said the National Liberation Army was responsible for both attacks. In one, the insurgents exploded dynamite on a dirt road as a police truck was passing, killing five policemen and wounding five, El Tiempo said. The attack was near the town of Curumani in the state of Cesar, 300 miles north of the capital, Bogota. Six civilians on a bus following the police truck also were wounded, the report said. A woman on the bus died of a heart attack a few hours later, El Tiempo said. The newspaper said that in the second attack, the guerrillas killed one policeman and wounded four others near the town of Tibu in Norte de Santander state, 320 miles northeast of the capital. The National Liberation Army has become the most active and most violent of five leftist guerrilla groups in Colombia. It is headed by a former Catholic priest, Manuel Perez. Authorities say the group regularly attacks army and police patrols. It has blown up the country's main oil pipeline dozens of times in the last three years. The group has said it will never negotiate peace with the government. However, another guerrilla group, the People's Liberation Army, released the Venezuelan president's brother-in-law to show its interest in reaching a settlement with the government, El Tiempo quoted a governor as saying. Norberto Rodriguez was kidnapped by the guerrilla group eight months ago near the Colombian city of Cucuta on the Venezuelan border. He was released Friday. The group freed Rodriguez, a former Venezuelan counsel, to show it is serious about seeking peace talks with the national government of President Virgilio Barco, Gov. Eduardo Yassaf was quoted by El Tiempo as saying. Yassaf, the governor of Norte de Santander, said the guerrillas stated their interest in talks in a communique they sent him. Another guerrilla group, the April 19 Movement, surrendered its weapons two months ago after nearly a year of peace talks with the government.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Critically Injured in Attack on Bus on Greyhound Route
LaserPhoto NS1
DOC.TEXT: The driver of a Southeastern Trailways bus taking a Greyhound route was shot and critically wounded, prompting strike-plagued Greyhound on Sunday to rule out contract talks until a week has passed without gunfire. ``It's an open-and-shut case of terrorism,'' said Fred G. Currey, chairman and chief executive officer of strike-plagued Greyhound Lines Inc. ``We will not negotiate with people who are involved in terrorism.'' Representatives of striking Greyhound drivers denied responsibility, but Currey said he would refuse to reopen talks until a week goes by without a shooting.
