The bus belonged to Southeastern Trailways, an independent company, but operated on Greyhound routes with Greyhound passengers under a pooling arrangement that existed before the strike, said Greyhound spokesman George Gravley. Southeastern Trailways has been carrying more Greyhound passengers than usual in recent weeks because of the strike, said Greyhound's Nashville Division general manager, Larry M. Glasscock Jr. About 6,300 Greyhound drivers nationwide went on strike March 2, and the company has reported 29 shooting attacks on its buses, 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents. A picket was killed March 3 in Redding, Calif., when he was crushed as a bus driven by a replacement driver was backing up. There were no charges filed in that incident. A $100,000 reward that Greyhound offered last week for information on strike-related violence will be offered in this case, Gravley said. The driver, David E. Bryant, 58, of Cincinnati underwent six hours of surgery Sunday at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. None of the 46 passengers was injured in the attack late Saturday on the bus heading from Nashville to Louisville, Ky. One of two men in a pickup truck that pulled up alongside the bus opened fire with a .44-caliber or .45-caliber handgun on Interstate 65 near White House, Tenn., about 30 miles north of Nashville, authorities said. The bullet entered the bus through a front window and struck the driver, a member of the union on strike against Greyhound, state Trooper Randy Pack said. Hospital spokesman Wayne Wood said the driver was in critical but stable condition. ``It's now a matter of just waiting and sort of seeing what happens,'' Wood said. ``If everything goes perfectly his arm will not need to be amputated. If there's a problem, unfortunately, that still could happen.'' Three of the passengers refused to board another bus for Louisville and were returned to Nashville on vans. Greyhound officials told leaders of the striking Amalgamated Transit Union on Thursday that Greyhound would return to the bargaining table on Monday. But on Friday, the company announced that it was calling off the meeting, citing continuing violence. ``They say they don't condone it,'' Currey told a news conference, ``but yet they don't do anything to stop it.'' The chairman flew from Dallas, where Greyhound is based, to Nashville early Sunday, but has unable to visit the driver. Joe Semmes, an executive board member for the union's Local 1613 in Nashville, said the shooting could not have been the work of union members because the driver is a union member. ``This shooting last night leads me to believe it is outside work and not related to any of our unions whatsoever,'' he said. ``This Southeastern Trailways is a member of the same labor organization we are.'' Currey said striking drivers must have been involved in the latest shooting, because until the strike began, Greyhound buses hadn't been fired on in the three years he has controlled the company. Semmes said Southeastern Trailways drivers were honoring picket lines by refusing to drive buses into terminals in Nashville and Knoxville. Instead, supervisors must do that job, he said. Semmes blamed the shootings on ``demented people.'' ``They hear Mr. Currey say he won't negotiate while this violence continues,'' he said. ``And they say `here's a good chance I can stir up a lot of trouble.''' Currey said he wanted to meet with Gov. Ned McWherter to see what measures can be taken to increase safety aboard Greyhound buses. He said he had offered to place two-way radios in buses that could be monitored by state troopers after shootings in Hamilton County, but said the governor had shown no interest. Authorities in at least two states, Florida and Ohio, installed radios aboard buses after shootings there. Currey said that, in the meantime, off-duty police will be riding Greyhound buses across Tennessee. An investor group that bought Greyhound in March 1987 purchased Trailways Lines Inc. four months later and merged the two under the Greyhound label, but the purchase did not affect 34 small, regional bus companies around the country that also use the Trailways name. Greyhound spokeswoman Liz Hale said Southeastern Trailways was not affected by the merger. By using non-striking and newly hired drivers, Greyhound increased its routes Sunday to 54 percent of its pre-strike runs.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Explosions Force Evacuation of Thousands in Sydney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with fire out, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gas explosions ripped through a cylinder plant in a suburb Sunday night, touching off a huge fire and forcing officials to evacuate thousands of people from nearby homes and close the international airport. Police Chief Superintendent Dennis Gillian said it was ``remarkable'' that no was killed or injured by the blasts. The fire burned for eight hours before firefighters extinguished it just before dawn and allowed people to return to their homes. The blasts occurred about 8:45 p.m. at an unidentified gas cylinder plant in St. Peters, a neighborhood about four miles south of downtown Sydney. The flames, which shot hundreds of feet into the air, quickly spread to a nearby asphalt factory, witnesses said. Homes within a two-mile radius of the fire were evacuated, forcing several thousand people to find other accomodations for the night. Intense heat from the explosions and fire melted power lines near the site. Authorities evacuated Kingsford Smith International Airport, about one mile away in the suburb of Botany, and closed plane routes over Sydney. They said the airport would not be reopened until the blaze was put out and authorities were sure that no further explosions were likely. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Brent Musburger Fired After CBS Contract Talks Break Down
DOC.TEXT: Brent Musburger, the primary voice of CBS Sports in the 1980s, was fired by the network Sunday after negotiations on a new contract broke down. The network announced that the broadcast of Monday's college basketball championship will be the last CBS assignment for Musburger, who had been scheduled to cover major-league baseball this summer. ``I was surprised, but it was a great run and I have a million memories, and I leave behind a lot of good friends,'' Musburger said in a statement read by Jimmy Tubbs, his personal assistant. ``At this time, I'm going to take an extended vacation, and I'll be working again someday, somewhere.'' Ted Shaker, executive producer of CBS Sports, said network officials believed Musburger's workload was too heavy, but that the broadcaster resisted attempts by CBS in contract talks to have him cut down. ``It's a difficult decision,'' said CBS Sports President Neal H. Pilson. ``It's never easy to deal with individuals with whom you have personal or business relationships.'' Musburger has been reported to earn between $1.6 million and $2 million per year from CBS. Pilson said he wouldn't describe the negotiations as ``a squabble over money,'' but refused to say what was in dispute. Pilson said negotiations for a new contract had been going on for several months between the network and Todd Musburger, who represents his brother. He said the Musburgers had asked for a decision by Sunday. Both Musburgers were unavailable Sunday but Tubbs, Musburger's assistant for 5{ years, said it had been apparent for several days that talks weren't going well. ``It wasn't right out of the blue,'' Tubbs said. ``Negotiations had been going on and they just broke off.'' Broadcasting the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball game between Duke and the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, will be the final CBS assignment for Musburger, the network said in announcing the decision. Musburger's 5{-year contract was to expire in July. Musburger is in his sixth season as lead play-by-play man for the NCAA basketball tournament and has been host of ``The NFL Today'' since 1975. He has anchored the Masters golf tournament, the NBA finals, the Pan American Games and late-night coverage of the U.S. Open tennis tournament. Musburger, who has been with CBS Sports since 1975, was scheduled to become the main voice for CBS' baseball coverage, which begins April 14. He also was in line to host the network's coverage of the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics. Industry speculation on a possible baseball replacement for Musburger centered on Al Michaels, said to be unhappy with his status at ABC. Michaels was unavailable to comment Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Airline Resumes Flights for Soviet Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Three flights with Soviet Jews arrived from Budapest on Sunday after the Hungarian state airline backed off its refusal to fly the immigrants to Israel. However, Gad Ben Ari, the spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency that is responsible for immigrants, said the situation was still confused for Jews wishing to come to Israel via Budapest. Malev airline cut off ticket sales and flights to Soviet emigrants last month because of threats from a pro-Iranian group called the Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine. The group threatened any airline that transported Soviet Jews to Israel. Palestinians and Arab governments have expressed fears that the large number of Jewish newcomers would be settled in the Israeli-occupied territories. Ben Ari said charter flights from the Soviet Union have not been resumed. But he said immigrants with Malev tickets bought in the Soviet Union for Tel Aviv can fly into Budapest and then continue from there with the airline on regular flights. No Malev tickets are being sold to Soviet immigrants in Hungary, however. Those who fly the Soviet airline Aeroflot to Budapest must wait for room on one of the special daily flights to Tel Aviv on Israel's El Al airline, the spokesman said. The flow of immigrants via Budapest resumed Friday when a few Soviet Jews arrived at Ben-Gurion Airport near Tel Aviv after Malev decided to honor their tickets bought in the Soviet Union, Ben Ari said. On Sunday, a large group of Soviets arrived in Tel Aviv from Budapest on two Malev fights and one by El Al Israel airlines, officials at the airport said. Malev's decision to cut off flights worried Israeli officials, since the Hungarian capital has been the exit route for Soviet Jews coming to Israel. The number of Soviet Jewish immigrants has greatly increased because of eased exit policies and fears of growing anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. The United States also has tightened its immigration policies. Israeli officials have estimated that up to 750,000 Soviet Jews may immigrate to Israel in the next few years.

DOC.HEAD: Report: City Owns At Least 52 Buildings Housing Clubs
With AM-Realty Reality, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At least 52 drinking and dancing clubs listed by the city as ``nuisances'' are on city-owned properties, making government the biggest landlord of the illegal establishments, according to published reports. A crackdown began after 87 people died March 25 at the Happy Land Social Club, an illegal social club in the Bronx, in an arson fire that was the deadliest blaze in the United States since 1977. The bodies of 48 of the victims were flown Sunday from Kennedy International Airport to Honduras aboard a DC-8 chartered by the American Red Cross. In all, 79 of the victims were believed to be Hondurans. ``Most of them went to the United States with high hopes, and they came back dead. We are very sad,'' said Honduran President Rafael Leonardo Callejas, who went to San Pedro Sulla to be with dozens of grieving relatives. A grand jury on Friday indicted 36-year-old Cuban immigrant Julio Gonzalez on charges of murder, arson, attempted murder and assault. He is accused of starting the fire with gasoline after being rejected by a former girlfriend who worked at the club. In the latest citywide social club sweep from Friday night to early Sunday, Social Club Task Force members visited 356 clubs and found 122 of them open, said police Sgt. Diane Kubler. They issued 54 vacate orders, 132 summonses and 193 notices of violation. One person was arrested. Clubs such as the Wanda Social Club, which was slapped with a vacate order Friday night, are a particular embarassment to the city. The city is the landlord. The New York Times, citing police records, reported Sunday that 52 of the 1,255 clubs listed as ``nuisance'' establishments were in properties owned by the city, including two in Housing Authority projects. The records portray the city as the largest landlord of such clubs. Buildings, finance and Department of Housing Preservation and Development records indicated there were 46 to 66 social clubs in city-owned buildings, department Commissioner Felice Michetti told the Times. Department inspectors were surveying them, she said. City-owned residential buildings house as many as 46 illegal clubs, the Daily News said Saturday, basing its report on a review of Buildings Department and real estate records as well as reports from inspections by city agencies. The News said the number could increase as city officials check contradictory listings of illegal clubs. The city inherited the clubs along with vast numbers of tenants and abandoned buildings, said Lee Jones, a spokesman for Mayor David N. Dinkins. ``Is it embarrassing?'' Jones said. ``It's something we're going to have to deal with.'' In the event of death or injury in a fire or other calamity, the city might be liable in lawsuits involving such establishments, the Times said. Ms. Michetti said there were two grounds for city action. If the tenant doesn't have a bona fide lease, ``we can bring an eviction action,'' she said. Otherwise, the city can move for a vacate order and ultimately padlock the property for violating fire and building codes or selling alcohol without a state license. The city has moved against two other city-owned social club tenants besides the Wanda, the Times said. Authorities last week issued a vacate order for a club in Manhattan and closed another in the Bronx.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Fusion Conference Concludes With Unanswered Questions
DOC.TEXT: Cold fusion's early promise of a clean, inexpensive energy source has faded as scientists struggle to understand the complexities of a phenomenon that continues to elude definition, researchers said. At the conclusion Saturday of the National Cold Fusion Institute's first international conference, about 200 researchers agreed only that a year of experimentation had produced some sort of nuclear process. ``We're not in a position now to say it's practical,'' said Charles Scott of Tennessee's Oak Ridge National Laboratory. ``It doesn't mean we won't be able to some day, but we certainly can't do it today.'' Still, many scientists left the three-day conference convinced the results of experiments substantiate claims made a year ago by chemists B. Stanley Pons of the University of Utah and Martin Fleischmann of England's University of Southampton. The two men's seeming breakthrough was questioned when researchers in other laboratories had trouble duplicating their results. While many scientists say they doubt cold fusion exists, experiments continue around the world. ``I think we should have the courage to say, if we feel so, that it is cold fusion,'' said physicist Guiliano Preparata of Italy's University of Milan. ``It has been proven to the extent that these phenomena are real, although they are not controllable ... the world is well-advised to take it seriously,'' Preparata said. Pons said that while it was still too early to draw any conclusions about a practical application, the work must go forward. ``You can't deny there's something here,'' he said. ``It may be a huge thing, it may not, but you have to look at it.'' Pons and Fleischmann announced in March 1989 that they had produced a nuclear fusion reaction by immersing a palladium and platinum electrode in deuterium oxide, or heavy water, then charging the device with electricity. They said deuterium atoms fused, giving off energy in the form of excess heat. At the time, it was suspected that sea water, which contains deuterium, might provide an inexhaustible source of fuel for the process. Nuclear fusion powers the stars. Traditionally scientists have believed that fusion could occur only at extremely high temperatures. Cool, small-scale fusion would provide a convenient, limitless source of power and be one of the greatest scientific discoveries of all time. The Utah Legislature appropriated $5 million to establish the National Cold Fusion Institute last August and to pursue patents to protect the state's commercial interests. However, the federal government has declined to fund the center and only two private companies are known to have donated money. Institute Director Fritz G. Will said that while deuterium is a vital part of the phenomenon, the possibility that the fusion reaction occurs inside the palladium electrode could leave prospects for a practical application ``dead in the water'' because of the rare metal's cost. Even so, many scientists said, the results of experiments in the United States, Japan, Italy, India and elsewhere pose intriguing questions about the nature of the nuclear processes that seem to be occurring. Many reported they'd observed excess heat, while others said their experiments had produced nuclear ``signatures'' such as tritium, neutrons and gamma rays. ``The big question is, what kind of fusion is going on?'' said Edmund Storms of Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. Storms, who has detected tritium in his experiments, suggested that more than one nuclear process might be taking place in the electrodes. The conference was not without skeptics. But even Richard Petrasso of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, who'd dismissed cold fusion as highly improbable, acknowledged that results so far warrant further research. ``I'm still skeptical, but I think there are some exciting things that need to be explained,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: More Arabs Killed By Other Arabs Than by Israeli Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: More Palestinians were killed by fellow Arabs than by Israeli soldiers during the first three months of 1990, and analysts said Sunday the figures reflect a decline in clashes with the army. According to a report issued by the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, 37 Palestinians died in inter-Arab violence. It said 30 Palestinians were shot to death by soldiers in confrontations in the 27-month-old uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The report noted that both tallies were lower than for the final three months of last year. During that period, army gunfire killed 64 Palestinians, and 43 were slain by fellow Arabs, said the center, which used figures compiled by The Associated Press to prepare its report. Palestinians killed by other Arabs were accused of dealing in drugs or prostitution, or of being Israeli informants, which Moslem fundamentalist groups consider crimes against the uprising. Arieh Shalev, a former commander of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, said the lower figures this year were a result of the decline in confrontations between soldiers and Palestinians during the uprising, known as the intefadeh. ``The intefadeh is different,'' he said. ``There are no more mass violent protests. Most of it is stone-throwing.'' An army spokesman, who could not be identified under regulations, said the reduction in the number of Palestinians killed by army gunfire was due to stricter rules for opening fire on Palestinian demonstrators. ``Things have changed from the beginning of the intefadeh when there was not much experience with this kind of unrest,'' he added. He said only officers or unit commanders are allowed to open fire _ and then only after firing warning shots. Sari Nusseibah, a leading Palestinian activist in Jerusalem, said the army had learned killing Palestinians hurt its image. Nusseibah said the underground leadership in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip had tried to curtail inter-Arab killings, and that the execution of suspected collaborators was something ``extraneous'' to the uprising. Shalev, in his telephone interview, said in some cases Palestinians were using the uprising to settle unrelated disputes. In the latest violence, a 24-year-old Palestinian prisoner was strangled Sunday in the Ketziot prison in southern Israel by a fellow inmate who accused him of collaborating with Israeli authorities, Arab reporters said. His death raised to 202 the number of Palestinians slain by other Arabs during the uprising. At least 670 have been killed by Israelis, and 43 Israelis have also died. In the West Bank, Arab reports said Murshed Fawzi Abu Hafiza, 27, the village leader in Alar, was found shot to death in his car. He had been attacked several times as a suspected collaborator. The reports said two friends who were with him told police he was killed when his gun accidentally discharged. Only Palestinians who work with Israel are allowed to have guns.

DOC.HEAD: April Fool's Day Weather No Joke in Louisiana, Arkansas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `In Louisiana ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with no injuries in Oak Grove, quote; picks up 5th graf, `Thunderstorms south ...'
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorms in parts of Louisiana and Arkansas took the roof off a building, downed trees and power lines and left hail up to 3 inches deep. A cold front advancing through the central United States brought up to 4 inches of wet, heavy snow to eastern North Dakota, winds gusting to 49 mph in Sioux Falls, S.D., and gusts to 46 mph in Ord, Columbus and Kearney, Neb. Showers and thunderstorms fell over southern Arkansas, northern Louisiana and northwestern Mississippi. In Oak Grove, La., thunderstorm winds ripped the roof off a trucking company building, said West Carroll Parish Deputy Wayne Yates. ``It rained real hard and the wind really came up. It made a mess. We had some trees and sheds blown across the roads,'' Yates said. No injuries were reported. Winds also downed trees and power lines north of Bastrop, La. Thunderstorms south of Magnolia, Ark., left the ground covered with dime-size hail 2 to 3 inches deep. Thunderstorms also developed in the southern High Plains. Scattered rain showers fell from eastern Wisconsin to central Kentucky. Light rain and drizzle dampened the lower Great Lakes region and the middle Atlantic Coast states, and fell across south-central and southeastern Texas. Ahead of the cold front, sunny skies prevailed in Kansas and Missouri. Skies were also mostly sunny in the West and the Southeast. Heavier rainfall during the six hours ending at 1 p.m. EDT included 1.54 inch at Cotulla, Texas. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 17 degrees in Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Outnumber Members Three-To-One at Supremacist Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A meeting of a fledgling white supremacist group led by a Bradley University student turned into a shouting match when about 30 protesters turned up at the public library to ridicule the gathering. No violence was reported and no arrests were made at Saturday's meeting by about 10 members of the American White Supremacist Party. Leader Matt Hale began reading a prepared script saying ``Blacks are an unproductive race that is destroying America. They will be stopped ...'' when the protesters interrupted him with laughter, shouts and singing. A police officer stood at the back of the room through most of the meeting, and intervened when the two groups began yelling at each other. Hale ``has a right to say what he wants, as far as we're concerned,'' said protester Ibaad Rahman, a Bradley University senior. ``But he has no right to infringe on the rights of other people. He has no right to outcast any race or religion.'' Hale attempted to start a chapter of the white supremacist group on the Bradley campus in February, but college officials prohibited it. Hale has continued his efforts to form a party chapter off campus. Hale, who says he supports race segregation, said he planned to hold another meeting later this month. ``I wish more white people would come,'' Hale said. ``I am here to speak to white people. I hope in the future our enemies, the communists (referring to the protesters) desist from our meetings.''

DOC.HEAD: Cable Crackdown May Not Happen, Broadcasters Told
DOC.TEXT: Despite consumer complaints about service and rates from some cable TV companies, Congress is unlikely to ``re-regulate'' the industry, lawmakers told the nation's broadcasters Sunday. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., told the National Association of Broadcasters convention that said a new ``must-carry'' rule, forcing cable companies to carry local stations, could pass the Congress. And Rep. Cardiss Collins, D-Ill., predicted, ``We are going to have a little, small, re-regulation bill.'' ``If you're looking for major re-regulation of cable, I don't see it _ and technology will make that decision obsolete,'' said Rep. Tom Tauke, R-Iowa, one of six Congressmen at the National Association of Broadcasters convention. Tauke was referring to Direct Broadcasting Satellite _ proposed high-power satellite services that can beam dozens of customer-selected channels direct to home antennas no more than 18 inches across. ``High-power DBS is going to happen. It's inevitable,'' said Tom Rogers, president of NBC Cable, a partner in the recently announced ``Sky Cable'' venture. Sky Cable hopes to launch its service with as many as 108 channels of programming available to some 4 million homes in 1993. Rogers said that while his service ``is technologically capable of being competitive to cable, the marketing scheme we've focused on is not intended to be directly competitive with cable.'' The company is considering having at least some customers ordering Sky Cable through their local conventional cable operator. And, he said, for the cable industry, since DBS is inevitable, ``it's better to be a part of it.''

DOC.HEAD: Underground Leader in Sri Lanka Leaves Hiding
DOC.TEXT: The country's top Tamil guerrilla leader emerged Sunday from his jungle hideout, where he had spent 2{ years commanding a guerrilla battle against Indian soldiers. ``We have successfully foiled the Indian military intervention,'' Velupillai Prabhakaran, 35, said at a military camp run by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the group he heads. ``I do not think there is any more need for me to live an underground life,'' he said. The last Indian soldiers left Sri Lanka a week ago after 30 months of a deadlocked jungle war against the Liberation Tigers. The withdrawal marked a turning point in relations between ethnic Tamil militants and the government, which is dominated by the country's Sinhalese majority. ``The Sinhalese people should realize the blunders of the past and be prepared to resolve our problems on the basis of human justice and righteousness,'' the burly guerrilla leader said in the Tamil language. ``If, on the other hand, justice is denied to our Tamil people and if oppression is unleashed ... we will not hesitate to resume the armed struggle to uphold the freedom of our people.'' Prabhakaran wore a green camouflage uniform and carried a revolver in an open holster. At least 50 guerrillas wearing bulletproof vests stood guard with automatic rifles. Snipers were posted on the roof of the building where the news conference was held. The Liberation Tigers and the government, which both wanted the Indians out, reached a peace accord last summer. Now, the Tigers have moved out of the jungles and swamps into areas vacated by the Indians to share policing duties with the government forces they once fought. But the Tigers have not given up their demand for independence, and the government has not announced what the political future of the Tamil-dominated north and east will be. ``There is peace and a cessation of hostilities between the Sri Lankan armed forces and the Tamil Tiger fighters,'' Prabhakaran said. ``But the fundamental problems of our people have not been resolved. Once concrete actions are taken to remove the causes and conditions that led to Tamil resistance, then the question ... will be resolved forever.'' The Tamil war for an independent nation began in 1983, touched off by decades-old complaints of discrimination by the Sinhalese in jobs, education and use of the Sinhalese language. Many militant groups, including Prabhakaran's, were based in the southern Indian city of Madras, where they were bolstered by the sympathies of India's 60 million Tamils. In July 1987, India brokered a peace accord between the Sri Lankan government and the militants, giving the Tamils limited autonomy in exchange for an arms surrender. India sent in peacekeeping soldiers to carry out the agreement. But the Liberation Tigers renounced the accord, and the Indian forces were caught up in vicious battles. At least 11,000 people, including 1,150 Indian soldiers, have died in the Tamil insurgency. In addition, the Tamil autonomy drive has generated a nationalist Sinhalese backlash, and that anti-government campaign has killed at least 7,000 people. Prabhakaran's last appearance in public was in August 1987, soon after he returned from New Delhi after talks with Indian government leaders. An eighth-grade dropout, Prabhakaran learned guerrilla warfare at a training camp in Lebanon run by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, headed by George Habash. Last summer, reports of Prabhakaran's death in a gunbattle with his No. 2 man, Ajith Mahathiya, surfaced in Sri Lanka and India. Asked Sunday about those reports, Prabhakaran just laughed.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Investigate Roller Coaster Crash That Hurt 35
DOC.TEXT: A roller coaster on which two cars crashed remained closed Sunday as experts tried to determine the cause of the accident that injured 35 people. A train of six cars on the ride at Worlds of Fun amusement park stopped about 100 feet from the end of the ride Saturday, and the following train slammed into it. At least 35 people, mostly teen-agers and young adults, suffered injuries ranged from bruises to a broken leg, Green said. Nine people were admitted to hospitals overnight, five for observation, he said. Each of the trains carried 24 people. The $3 million Timber Wolf roller coaster, built by Dinn Inc., was shut Sunday as engineers and electricians checked the equipment, Green said. The experts weren't immediately able to determine what caused the accident, which occurred on the first day the park opened for the season, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dutch Guards Reportedly Foil Attempt To Free U.S. Sergeant
DOC.TEXT: Dutch prison guards foiled an attempt by 12 Americans, including several servicemen, to seize a U.S. Air Force sergeant imprisoned on charges of killing his wife, television reports said Sunday. A Justice Ministry spokesman reacted by warning of ``a serious diplomatic conflict,'' according to Dutch television. Television reports said the incident occurred Friday after the Dutch High Court ruled that Sgt. Charles Donald Short could not be extradited to the United States to stand trial on the murder charges. The 12 U.S. citizens, including several members of the U.S. Air Force, were waiting in several cars with U.S. license plates outside a jail in the central Dutch city of Utrecht, the television said. Short was due to return there from the High Court ruling in The Hague, 37 miles away, according to the report. Prison guards who saw the Americans asked them what they were doing, and the guards were told the men were waiting for Short to take him to the United States, apparently for trial, the report said. There was no immediate word of how the guards thwarted them or whether the Americans were armed. The television report quoted a Justice Ministry spokesman as saying, ``The (12) Americans are way off the mark here. They should keep their paws off Short, or else there will be a serious diplomatic incident.'' The spokesman was not identified in the report. A security guard at the ministry said no spokesman could be reached until Monday. The television report quoted Short's unidentified defense attorney as saying the Americans were trying to mount ``a little Panama.'' It was a reference to the U.S. invasion of that nation in December to topple dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Short was arrested on April 1, 1988, and accused of killing his Turkish-born wife, cutting her body into pieces and dumping the remains in plastic bags in Monnikendam, 56 miles from the U.S. Air Force base at Soesterberg. He was serving there with the 32nd Tactical Fighter Squadron. He was transferred to U.S. military police a few days later, but he was eventually handed back to Dutch authorities for trial. The High Court ruled Short's extradition would be illegal since he could be sentenced to death if convicted of murder by a U.S. court. However, it is still unclear whether Dutch courts will be legally competent to try him. If not, he could be released, according to the television report. The United States asked for Short's extradition soon after his arrest. But Dutch law, which has no capital punishment, routinely bans extradition in cases that could lead to the suspect being executed.

DOC.HEAD: Man Wanted In Wife's Stabbing Hit By Lightning
DOC.TEXT: A man sought for questioning in the stabbing of his wife was in critical condition Sunday after being struck by lightning, authorities said. Kevin Callahan's wife, Janet, was in critical but stable condition at the same hospital, Bayfront Medical Center. Her husband was found semiconscious at 8 a.m. Saturday on a fishing catwalk at the Gandy Bridge, police said. He muttered to rescuers that he was wanted by police, the Pinellas County Sheriff's Department said. Doctors determined he had been hit by lightning, said sheriff's spokeswoman Marianne Pasha. Mrs. Callahan was stabbed in the throat and back with a large butcher knife on Thursday, police said. St. Petersburg police charged Callahan, 32, with aggravated battery Saturday afternoon as he lay in a hospital bed.

DOC.HEAD: Rape Victim Says Assailant Quoted Williams During Attack
DOC.TEXT: A woman told authorities a man who sexually assaulted her at knifepoint quoted Republican gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams, who last weekend compared foul weather to rape, police said. According to the police report, the man told the 30-year-old woman she should ``relax and enjoy it ... Like Clayton Williams said, it's inevitable.'' The woman was bound and sexually assaulted by the man, who broke into her apartment and waited for her to return home Thursday night, said police Sgt. Hector Reveles. Police had no suspects in the attack. Williams drew criticism from Democrats and women's groups for comparing foggy, drizzly weather on his ranch to rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' he told cowhands and reporters March 24. Williams apologized for the remark. Asked Sunday to comment on the attack, Williams' press secretary, Bill Kenyon, said Sunday, ``This violent incident is so awful and appalling that out of respect for the victim we have no comment.'' The Democratic candidates, State Treasurer Ann Richards and Attorney General Jim Mattox, meet in a runoff April 10 for their party's nomination.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Requiring Fungicide-Free Certification For Some Wine Imports
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government is requiring some French and Italian vineyards to certify that their wines do not contain traces of a fungicide not approved in the United States before shipping the wines to this country, a spokesman said Sunday. ``We have found a little bit of Italian sparking wine and some French wine that contains traces of a fungicide not approved in the United States,'' said Food and Drug Administration spokesman Bill Grigg. He said there is no ban on the wines, but the vineyards involved must retain independent testing labs to certify that the wines are fungicide-free before shipping them to the United States. The FDA will conduct spot tests on the wines to reaffirm the certifications, he said. The fungicide, procymidone, is made in Japan and is applied to grapes while they are growing rather than to the wines themselves, said Grigg. Grigg said he did not have figures on the amount of wine involved, but that it was a tiny percentage of total exports from the two countries to the United States. He also said there is no indication that the fungicide _ which is approved for use in Europe _ constitutes a health risk. But because it has not undergone U.S. clearance procedures, he said, it cannot be allowed.

DOC.HEAD: 120,000 Demonstrators Demand Emigration Freedom for Soviet Jews
With AM-Israel-Soviet Jews
By CHRIS SHERIDAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 120,000 demonstrators gathered outside the United Nations Sunday to voice support for Soviet Jewish emigration and to express rage at reports of growing anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. The ralliers, who packed Dag Hammersjold Plaza, also called for direct flights from Moscow to Tel Aviv. The rally came six days after Malev, the Hungarian airline, halted flights between Budapest and Tel Aviv because of threats by the radical group Islamic Jihad to attack airliners carrying Soviet emigres. The airline resumed limited flights from Budapest to Tel Aviv Sunday, but still wasn't running direct charter flights from Moscow. Arab nations have asked the Soviet Union to slow the tide of emigrating Soviet Jews. ``To stand resolute against these terrorist threats is to defeat their cowardly perpetrators,'' said President George Bush, in a statement read at the rally. ``Soviet Jews must be allowed free and unimpeded transit as well as direct flights to Israel.'' Several other prominent politicians and dignitaries addressed the crowd, which police estimated at 120,000. They included New York City Mayor David Dinkins, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., New York State Attorney General Robert Abrams, novelist Elie Wiesel, Israel's Consul General Uriel Savir, former Mayor Edward I. Koch and refusenik Natan Scharansky, who emigrated from the Soviet Union in 1986. Messages of support were sent by Vice President Dan Quayle, New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., and Cardinal John O'Connor, head of the New York Archdiocese. Each of the speakers praised the Soviet Union for allowing greater emigration, but also cautioned that the battle continues. ``When you hear that there are wonderful leaders in the Soviet Union, don't believe this,'' Scharansky told the ralliers. ``It is you who made all these changes possible, it's your struggle to change our future.'' Under Mikhail Gorbachev's leadership, Soviet authorities have let thousands of Jews leave the country. In 1986, only 914 were allowed to emigrate. Thousands of Jews are presently trying to leave the Soviet Union for Israel. But there are no direct flights between the Soviet Union and Israel, so emigres must travel via third countries, such as Hungary or Czechoslovakia. Speakers expressed alarm over reports that anti-Semitism is growing in the Soviet Union. ``Jews are terrified over threats to their life and limb,'' said Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, the chairman of the Greater New York Coalition for Soviet Jewry, the rally's sponsor. ``We say to Mikhail Gorbachev, we have nothing against you or the Soviet Union. But we demand that you crush the anti-Semitic savages in your country,'' he said. ``Bigotry among some Soviets is becoming their first exercise in free thought,'' said Mayor Dinkins. ``But Soviet Jews haven't come so far to be disappointed so soon.''

DOC.HEAD: Blockade of Indian Land Remains After Helicopter Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf pvs, `State police failed...,' to UPDATE with Indians' conditions for allowing investigators on their land. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `A National Guard...
DOC.TEXT: State police with shotguns blockaded a Mohawk Indian community Sunday for a third straight day since gunfire forced down a Vermont National Guard helicopter and wounded a doctor on a medical mission. While the blockade of the Ganienkeh Mohawk Territory continued, negotiators were trying to work out an agreement to investigate the shooting, which wounded a civilian doctor aboard the helicopter. The Indians, insisting that a police investigation would be an invasion of the Ganienkeh territory, said they would die to protect the sovereignty of their community near the Canadian border, about 150 miles north of Albany. Hundreds of troopers were outside the community. State police said several armed Mohawks, several with AK-47 assault rifles, were seen inside the isolated and secretive traditional Indian community where an estimated 40 families live. State police failed again Sunday to persuade the Indians to allow investigators into the area, but said they would resume the negotiations Monday. An Indian spokesman, Daryl Martin, said late Sunday the Indians would be willing to allow an independent investigation team onto their land, as long as the results were reported simultaneously to both sides. State troopers wouldn't be excluded from the team, as long as the Mohawks believed they could be impartial, Martin said. A National Guard crew flew the damaged helicopter off the Ganienkeh land and back to Vermont Sunday afternoon, said state police Capt. Richard Garrant. The Mohawks had allowed a crew on the territory to repair the craft. Two state police helicopter overflights of the Ganienkeh land Saturday determined that the shots were fired by a gunman standing near a building on the territory, said state police Maj. Robert Leu. Daryl Martin, a spokesman for the Indians, insisted the shots did not come from the encampment. Mohawk roadblocks were set up beside police blockades after the shooting to keep authorities from coming onto the settlement, Martin said. State police patrolled blockades on the four roads leading into the encampment. The crew chief of the National Guard helicopter, Sgt. Kris Samples, saw a man fire a rifle at the chopper, Leu said. Samples flew with state police investigators Saturday and pointed out where he saw the gunman, Leu said. Another witness, a man who had been driving a pickup truck on a nearby road and heard the shots, corroborated Samples' account, Leu said. Investigators took aerial photographs of the area, Leu said. Tensions spiked Saturday afternoon when talks broke off and the Mohawks said they were preparing for violence. By nightfall, though, tensions eased and negotiators were preparing to continue their discussions. State police want permission to send three investigators onto the Ganienkah land for one hour, but the Indians, like other Mohawks in northern New York, claim federal or state authorities have no jurisdiction on their land. ``Sovereignty is the bottom line,'' said Dennis Curtin, a Plattsburgh attorney representing the Indians. ``The position of the Indians is that no outside investigation is going to be done on the territory.'' Trooper Richard Garcia said the helicopter was flying at about 200 feet when it was fired on about 11:30 a.m. Friday. Dr. James Van Kirk, 27, was recovering from a gunshot wound at Vermont Medical Center in Burlington, where he works. Three military crew members, Van Kirk and a civilian nurse were aboard the UH-1 helicopter, which was flying from Burlington to Massena, N.Y., to pick up a seriously ill patient. Snow forced the helicopter to abort its mission and it was returning to Vermont when the shots were fired. The Ganienkeh encampment has its roots in a centuries-old land claim by the Mohawks, who say the land is among 9 million acres in New York and Vermont wrongfully taken from them in the 18th century. The state gave the Mohawks the use of the Ganienkeh land in 1977 as part of a settlement that ended a three-year Mohawk occupation of land at Moss Lake, about 100 miles southwest of Altona. In October 1974, a 22-year-old man and a 9-year-old girl were shot and wounded while riding in cars near Moss Lake, and the Indians also refused to cooperate. No one was ever charged. State Attorney General Robert Abrams sued the Ganienkeh Indians to try to close a bingo hall that opened in 1988. Busloads of people normally travel on weekends to the territory to play high-stakes bingo, but the buses were turned back at the roadblocks throughout the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead, Four Injured As Gunman Opens Fire on Socialists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with details on dead and injured; ADDS statements by government and parties, details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: An attacker in a passing car Sunday fired at a barricade erected by socialists campaigning on Crete for next week's national elections, killing one person and wounding four, police said. The socialists erected the roadblock to stop conservative New Democracy party leader Constantine Mitsotakis from approaching Iraklion's city center to address a rally, police said. A police official identified the dead man as Manolis Iakoumakis, 37, a cook who lived in Iraklion. The injured were in stable condition at the city hospital, he said. No one had been arrested in the shootings, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Panhellenic Socialist Movement said the dead man and one of the four injured were party members. New Democracy claimed that one of the wounded, journalist Costas Papagiorgiou, was one of its supporters. New Democracy spokesman Nikos Anastassopoulos accused the socialists of instigating the violence by setting up the barricade. ``We fear that there is a scheme to create tension in the last days of the election campaign,'' he said in a telephone interview. Anastassopoulos said socialist supporters had not heeded repeated calls to remove the barrier. A spokesman for the Panhellenic Socialist Movement alleged that the shots were fired from a car in the New Democracy entourage. Anastassopoulos said he could not comment on the claim because he had not been fully briefed. Mitsotakis' entourage passed through the roadblock shortly after the shooting, and the rally was held as scheduled. Socialist leader Andreas Papandreou, the former premier, accused New Democracy of ``systematized provocation. '' He called on his supporters to help restore calm. On Saturday, Premier Xenophon Zolotas fired National Intelligence Chief Dimitris Angelopoulos. The premier said Angelopoulos had been slow in briefing him on allegations that intelligence agents were jamming broadcasts of a television station allied to the socialists. President Christos Sartzetakis dissolved the 300-member parliament on March 12 in preparation for the elections. New Democracy had held 148 seats and the socialists had held 128. The Communist Party held most of the remaining seats.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Tracing of Sex Partners Unlikely To Control Syphilis
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to notify the sex partners of syphilis patients is unlikely to control the spread of the disease because many of those infected have multiple anonymous partners, according to a study released Sunday. The results, reported in Monday's issue of the Annals of Internal Medicine, suggest that efforts to fight AIDS by notifying patients' partners is likely to fail, too, said an accompanying editorial in the journal. The 1988 study, conducted by Oregon health officials and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control focused on 146 syphilis-infected adults treated over four months. Overall the patients were able to identify an average of just one in five of their sexual partners, according to the report. Twenty-eight percent of the patients reported exchanging sex for drugs or money, and that group accounted for 72 percent of the unlocatable sexual partners. ``A strategy of controlling syphilis which relies solely or mostly on partner notification is doomed to failure because it is _ at most _ only 20 percent effective,'' said one of the study's authors, Dr. David Fleming of the Oregon Health Division. Oregon state law requires that syphilis cases be reported to county and state health officials. Each patient had an average of five sex partners during the study period whom they could not identify sufficiently for partner notification, the study found. In contrast, a comparison group of 164 Oregon adults with gonorrhea, which is also sexually transmitted, reported an average of less than one anonymous sex partner. Syphilis, a chronic, sexually transmitted disease, is at its highest national rate in 40 years, infecting about 16 people out of every 100,000. In 1988, 39,000 cases were reported, according to the CDC. Because of syphilis' long infectious period and the likelihood that some patients engage in prostitution or drug use, the researchers said partner notification won't control its spread. Because AIDS is prevalent among those with multiple sex partners and intravenous drug users, partner notification for those patients will be ``fraught with the same problems,'' Fleming said. Instead, contact tracing should be supplemented by vigorous and aggressive voluntary screening and educational programs, the researchers said. ``Despite a medical treatment for syphilis, the resurgence of this disease in the heterosexual population may be an alarming prelude to an epidemic of AIDS in the same population,'' the researchers wrote. The editorialist, Allan Brandt of Harvard Medical School, said that despite calls for mandatory contact tracing of AIDS patients, the Oregon study points out ``the great uncertainty that (partner notification) effectively serves the goals of public health and welfare.''

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes, Sets Houses on Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with flight plan suggesting plane may have had a passenger, other details; RESTORES dropped word `person' in lead. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Lee Hill...
DOC.TEXT: A light plane swooped out of the foothills and crashed into a vacant home and several outbuildings, killing at least one person and setting three buildings on fire. The twin-engine private plane smashed into the only vacant home in the neighborhood, said city spokesman David Grimm. It hit four or five garages and other outbuildings, setting the home and two of the outbuildings on fire. Paint stored in one of the buildings fed a fierce blaze. Firefighters recovered one body from the wreckage of the plane, Grimm said, adding that it was burned beyond recognition. A flight plan raised the possibility there was a passenger on the plane, but searchers failed to find a second body, authorities said after nightfall Sunday. Eyewitnesses reported seeing a twin-engine plane obviously in trouble. ``The engine was screaming wildly,'' said Gary Faris, who watched from his back yard. The plane swooped low along a ridge, its wing dipping low. ``It went out of sight and a second later we heard the impact,'' Faris said. The plane crashed between 3 p.m. and 4 p.m. MDT on the northwest edge of Boulder, a city of about 100,000 that is 30 miles northwest of Denver. A flight plan filed for the Cessna 421-C indicated it took off from the Denver area at 1:50 p.m. Sunday to take a passenger to Granby, across the Continental Divide in the Colorado Rockies, then return to Denver, said Verlin B. Tranter, an investigator for the National Transportation Board. Investigators had yet to determine if the plane made it to Granby and was returning or had turned back with two people on board, he said. The plane was owned by Skyways Associates of Raton, N.M. Lee Hill, a spokesman for Boulder Community Hospital, said one man was admitted shortly after the crash with hip injuries. The man, Harold Parks, 54, was working in his garage when the plane crashed, said Steve Davis, a Boulder County deputy sheriff and Parks' stepson, who saw the plane crash and rushed over to find Parks lying on the ground. ``He appeared to be OK,'' Davis said. ``I kicked in a door looking for my mom, who was gone. My stepfather said he heard a loud explosion and was literally blown out of the garage about 40 yards.'' Also Sunday in Highland, N.Y., a single-engine plane struck a 300-foot broadcast tower atop a fog-bound mountain and crashed, killing the pilot, state police said. The name of the pilot, alone aboard the Cessna, was withheld. Broadcasting from the tower 50 miles north of New York City was uninterrupted, said Jerry Lademan of WEOK in Poughkeepsie, one of several stations that use the tower.

DOC.HEAD: Son Attacks U.S. Agency For Extraditing Father on War Crime Charges
DOC.TEXT: The son of a man extradited for Nazi war crimes confronted the federal investigators who helped send his father to Yugoslavia at an international conference Sunday on the Holocaust. Radoslav Artukovic said the Nazi-hunting Office of Special Investigations built the case against his father, Andrija Artukovic, by relying on forged documents. Officials of the OSI, a U.S. Justice Department agency whose role in the extradition is under federal investigated, deny the allegation. The fifth annual Boston College law school conference on the Holocaust and human rights law was attended by prosecutors, academics and Nazi hunters, including Beate Klarsfeld of France. In the Holocaust during World War II the Nazis systematically killed 6 million Jews, as well as homosexuals, Gypsies and others considered undesirable. Andrija Artukovic was extradited in 1986. Dubbed the ``Butcher of the Balkans,'' he was convicted in Yugoslavia of ordering the deaths of more than 1,000 people and of complicity in hundreds of thousands of other concentration camp deaths. He died of natural causes in a prison hospital in 1988 while awaiting execution. Artukovic claims his father was innocent and has repeatedly questioned the extradition. On Sunday, the Los Alamitos, Calif., stockbroker and former military police investigator accused the OSI team of relying on falsified evidence from a communist country in order to extradite his father. The elite unit was able to extradite the senior Artukovic because extradition is performed at the request of a foreign country. It doesn't require due process in a U.S. court. Artukovic said he had State Department cables suggesting the OSI solicited the Yugoslavian request for his father's extradition. OSI Deputy Director Bruce Einhorn denied the accusations at the conference. ``OSI does not operate a service for begging and demanding extradition from other countries,'' he said. ``Other countries are grown up ... they have to make the decision about whether they want someone extradited.'' Artukovic also accused the OSI of holding back facts that would have discredited affidavits from several witnesses whose testimony was crucial to the extradition. In addition, Artukovic said, OSI officials misled a Los Angeles court by de-emphasizing the office's role in soliciting information from Yugoslavia about Artukovic. The Justice Department has confirmed in written replies to members of Congress that internal auditors in the Office of Professional Responsibility have begun investigating the allegations. Einhorn declined to comment on the investigation. ``As far as were concerned, we think the case should be over,'' he said. ``We deny that anyone at OSI committed any misconduct. We believe our office acted properly and we believe the courts'' support that. Artukovic said he undertook his crusade because he wants his father's body back from the Yugoslavian government, which has refused to return it.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-democracy Protesters Take to Nepal's Streets
DOC.TEXT: Pro-democracy protesters pressed their demands Sunday as people marched through the capital area with sticks and knives, doctors went on strike and lawyers rallied at the prime minister's office. Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha reshuffled his Cabinet, where divisions have surfaced over how to handle the growing protest movement. In the Katmandu suburb of Patan, men, women and children poured into the streets demanding an end to alleged police brutality. Two demonstrators were killed by police gunfire over the two previous days, and 20 were wounded. On Sunday, hundreds of protesters carried sticks, metal rods and kitchen knives. Residents had dug trenches overnight and erected barricades on major streets to prevent police from sending reinforcements. During the day, police removed many of the large mounds of boulders, logs and garbage cans placed across the streets. At least 14 people have been killed in Nepal since Feb. 18, when the movement for multiparty democracy was launched by two banned political parties in this Himalayan kingdom. Hundreds of people _ including doctors, lawyers, students and journalists _ have been arrested. Doctors, nurses and other workers went on strike at hospitals in the Katmandu Valley on Sunday, defying a government warning that employees of essential services should not strike. Only skeleton staffs remained on duty to deal with emergency cases. About 250 lawyers marched to the prime minister's office to demand the release of 64 jailed attorneys. Shrestha was not in his office, and the protesters left a memo demanding the detainees be freed by Wednesday. One marcher, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the lawyers also were demanding that government forces stop shooting women and children and investigate all cases of police gunfire since the protests began. The demonstrators seek to change Nepal's system of non-partisan government, which divides power between King Birendra and the National Assembly. Shrestha reshuffled his Cabinet on Sunday following the resignation of Foreign Minister Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya, who said the government should have held talks with the protesters. Shrestha dropped nine of the 29 members in the Council of Ministers. Government-owned Radio Nepal gave no reason for the firings. But well-placed sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the sacked ministers had differences with the prime minister. They did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to restore writethru designation.
Fuel Slick Threatens Water Supplies in Pittsburgh, Other Communities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `The company said...,' with governor declaring state of emergency. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `The 30-mile-long...
DOC.TEXT: A 30-mile-long fuel slick left a town of about 15,000 people without normal water Sunday, and threatened water supplies in Pittsburgh and dozens of other cities dependent on the Allegheny and Ohio rivers, authorities said. The slick moving sluggishly down the Allegheny northwest of Pittsburgh resulted from a landslide that cracked a pipeline Friday. The pipeline released a mixture of gasoline, kerosene and lesser amounts of other fuels into a tributary creek at Freeport about 35 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. Buckeye Pipeline Co. estimated it lost about 98,000 gallons of fuel from the 10-inch-wide pipeline linking Linden, N.J., and the Pittsburgh suburb of Coraopolis. The company said it recovered about 20 percent of the spilled fuel, and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency estimated that 75,600 gallons leaked into Knapp Run Creek, then into the Allegheny. The cleanup continued Sunday. Pennsylvania Gov. Robert P. Casey on Sunday declared a state of emergency along the section of the Allegheny affected by the spill. ``Suffice it to say, there is still a high level of concern,'' Casey said. ``But we believe the situation is being dealth with adequately.'' The 30-mile-long slick was at least five miles northeast of Pittsburgh, city water department engineer Alex Sciulli told an evening news conference. ``This spill has been very difficult to track,'' Sciulli said. Many water treatment plants cannot filter out the fuels in the spill, said Allegheny County Health Director Albert Brunwasser. Officials were trying to develop a treatment program, he said. In Harrison Township, a city of about 15,000 people nearly 35 miles northeast of Pittsburgh, residents had to rely on water brought by truck and tanker to community fire stations, said county Deputy Fire Marshal Nat Mastro. In a worst-case scenario, about 50,000 people in more than 30 communities that get their water from the Allegheny could be without it by Monday, Mastro said. In Pittsburgh, officials said they expected to shut down the city's water intakes, leaving at least a three-day reserve. Mayor Sophie Masloff has asked all residents in the city of about 400,000 people to reduce water use, Sciulli said. If residents cooperate, the reserve could last an additional two days. ``We feel we're in very good shape,'' Sciulli said. Officials in other communities were not as optimistic. Brackenridge Emergency Management Director Dennis Vrotny said fire departments in his community and others were drawing as much water as possible from tributaries to the Allegheny to add to their reservoirs.Vrotny said coperation from residents was essential. ``I don't think it's going to hold if people don't conserve now,'' he said. ``As it is, we're losing ground fast.'' The water system in Brackenridge, a community of about 4,000, serves 30,000 people, Vrotny said. Eight municipal water authorities that draw supplies from the Ohio up to 12 miles northwest of Pittsburgh were asked to begin saving water in case the slick reaches them, said Beaver County Emergency Services Director Russell Chiodo. The Ohio flows out of the juncture of the Allegheny and Monongahela in Pittsburgh. The authorities serve about 40,000 people, Chiodo said. ``We want them to be conservative as all heck right now,'' he said. ``We don't know what's going to happen.'' Eighty-five cleanup workers from Buckeye Pipeline and contractors used absorbent pads attached to floating booms to remove oil from the Allegheyny said Charles Kleeman, the EPA's Pittsburgh administrator. The state Department of Environmental Resources and county health laboratories tested river water samples to determine the extent of pollution and whether the fuel-laced water was flammable, Kleeman said. Federal, state and county emergency management officials said experience from a 4 million-gallon spill two years ago on the Monongahela helped this weekend's cleanup. The spill has not affected the Monongahela.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Urges Managers to Buy Chrysler Stock
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca is encouraging about 100 top managers to buy company stock, tying their personal finances to the company they run, a Chrysler spokesman said. ``It started with just a feeling on our top management's part that our management should take greater stock in the future of the company by sharing in the same risks and rewards as the shareholders,'' Steve Harris, director of Chrysler's corporate public relations, said Sunday. The program, which affects about 100 top executives, began a few weeks ago, Harris said. The move comes with Chrysler stock standing at $16.62{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange, down about 37 percent from its high over the past year. Harris said the program aims at making the executives accountable, something Chrysler has been stressing in the last year. In July, Chrysler asked 2,000 top executives to voluntarily put into escrow up to 10 percent of their salary, as part of a $1-billion, 15-month cost-cutting program.

DOC.HEAD: More Telly For Britons, But Fewer Couch Potatoes Tuning In
Also moved in advance.
DOC.TEXT: When there were only four television channels in Britain, watching ``telly'' was the country's favorite pasttime and viewers boasted British programs were the best in the world. Now that government deregulation is bringing a smorgasbord of conventional and satellite TV channels to British homes, studies show audiences have dropped by 10 percent. Half of those still watching grumble about the programming. It's a paradox that is troubling an industry in upheaval as the latest target of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's selloff of state-owned or regulated enterprises. Until last year when publisher Rupert Murdoch introduced satellite television to Britain, television was neatly carved among four networks _ two run by the state-funded British Broadcasting Corp. and two by private companies. Now, legislation before the House of Commons calls for auctioning off all the commercial TV franchises and the creation of a fifth land-based TV channel. It is the most radical overhaul since commercial networks were first allowed to compete with the venerable BBC in 1955. A private consortium, meanwhile, is about to launch Britain's second satellite TV network, British Satellite Broadcasting, to compete with Murdoch's money-losing Sky Television. All that's missing are the viewers. Britons still watch an average of about 25{ hours of television every week. But that's a 10 percent drop from five years ago, despite the arrival of overnight television in 1987 and then Sky. ``Some of this (drop) is attributable to video, but the same period saw a considerable increase in alternative leisure activities _ taking two or more holidays, eating out,'' said Barry Cox, director of London Weekend Television. Bernard Bennett, LWT's controller of research, thinks ``the existing cake will have to be carved up in a larger number of portions'' to accommodate the new channels. First on the air will be British Satellite Broadcasting, the international consortium awarded the government franchise to use the five satellite channels allocated to Britain under an international treaty. The $2 billion consortium is the second-largest private sector investment project in Britain after Eurotunnel, the tunnel under the English Channel between England and France. The five BSB channels, including a movie channel trumpeting deals with six of the top eight Hollywood studios, will go head-to-head beginning April 29 with the four channels of Sky Television. Sky already is losing $3.2 million a week. ``Neither of us has any clue whether there's room for one or room for two,'' admitted BSB spokesman Edward Bickham. ``On a financial basis, we have the ability to spread the risks of the project across a number of major companies. No one has to bet their business on BSB.'' Referring to an industry study showing 44 percent of viewers saying they find nothing appealing when they want to watch television, Bickham said, ``We believe there's a lot of room for extra choice.'' ``We're not trying to take over the market from the (four existing) generalist channels, but offering a complimentary service alongside,'' he said. BSB expects to be in 1 million of Britain's 22 million homes by the end of the year and in 3 million, its break-even point, by the end of 1991. Channel 5, the proposed new land-based commercial channel, probably will not begin broadcasting until the mid-1990s because of a wrangle over the type of transmission system. Even then, it will reach only 70 percent of households, and all their video recorders will have to be retuned to avoid interference. At present the BBC carries no advertisements and the two commercial networks do. There are 15 regional franchises awarding to companies that broadcast on the commercial networks. They will all be put on the auction block in 1993. There's no guarantee that any of the existing companies, such as London Weekend Television, makers of ``Upstairs Downstairs,'' or Granada Television, which brought out ``The Jewel in the Crown,'' will retain their franchises. In fact, Michael Grade, chief executive of the existing Channel 4 commercial network, predicts few of the present companies will have the money to compete with the powerful consortia bidding against them. ``They may make what they know to be a sensible bid and still lose to a group which is much more optimistic or has simply got its sums wrong,'' Grade told a recent American Chamber of Commerce luncheon. ``Is it really right, I ask, to hand out broadcasting licenses to people who, for whatever reason, may simply be offering too much money for them?''

DOC.HEAD: Former Arbitrager Due for Release This Week After Serving Two Years
DOC.TEXT: Ivan F. Boesky, Wall Street's most notorious felon, will be a free man this week. The former arbitrager is due for release on Wednesday, just over two years after he entered prison for his role in the nation's biggest insider trading scandal, a source close to Boesky said Sunday. This week's date has limited practical meaning, though. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Boesky was released into home custody about six weeks ago and has been required only to make weekly visits to a Brooklyn halfway house. Wednesday's release ``does mean that he won't have to report back in their once a week,'' he said. The source would say only that Boesky was living somewhere in the New York area and was in good spirits. Boesky owns a 75-acre estate north of New York City, which he has been renovating recently. ``I think his state of mind is quite good,'' the source said. A call to the federal Bureau of Prisons to confirm the release date was answered by a recording saying the office would reopen Monday morning. Officials at New York City's Metropolitan Corrections Center said only the federal office would confirm the release date. In November 1986, Boesky paid $100 million to the Securities and Exchange Commission and agreed to plead guilty to one felony to settle charges related to Wall Street's biggest insider-trading case. He was sentenced to three years in prison but is being released a year early for good behavior. Boesky was sent to the minimum-security Lompoc Federal Prison Camp in California in March 1988, where he earned 11 cents an hour for working on a prison cleanup crew. Last December, he was transfered to the Brooklyn halfway house. After his formal release this week, Boesky will have to report to a probation officer once a month for six months, the source said. As for his future, the source said he didn't think Boesky would make any plans until after giving testimony in the racketeering and fraud case against former junk bond pioneer Michael Milken. Boesky agreed to testify against Milken as part of his plea bargain with federal authorities. The case against the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive has been delayed and may not go to trial before next year. In addition to helping the government's case against Milken's, Boesky also provided information that resulted in a record $650 million plea-bargain settlement by Drexel. Drexel is being liquidated following its parent's decision to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Shoe Executive Dead
DOC.TEXT: Harry S. Robinson II, a retired 35-year veteran of the United States Shoe Corp., died Friday. He was 69. Robinson died of cancer at his home. He had been credited as a key figure in the recent growth of U.S. Shoe, a Cincinnati-based company whose businesses include footwear, eyeglasses, contact lenses and women's apparel. During his career, Robinson served as advertising manager and as a vice president and president of the company's Red Cross Shoe Division. He was group vice president when he retired. He also was a past president of the Speech and Hearing Center of Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: Southmark Strikes Deal with Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Southmark Corp. and its unsecured creditors have agreed on a new bankruptcy reorganization plan, the real estate holding company said Sunday. The agreement, to be filed with the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Dallas, calls for a quicker payout to creditors than the company offered in its original reorganization proposal. The new plan also restructures some securities and proposes a reduction in payout to Southmark's equity holders, the company said. ``Since filing Chapter 11 last July, our objective has been to avoid lengthy and expensive litigation and to provide prompt distributions from the estate,'' Board Chairman Arthur G. Weiss said in a statement. The unsecured creditors had presented the biggest obstacle to a reorganization plan put forward by Southmark in January. That plan called for the company to sell nearly all of its assets except for its Houston-based thrift, San Jacinto Savings Association. Southmark officials then projected total payments to creditors of $284 million. Unsecured creditors, mainly holders of over $1 billion in Southmark's junk bonds, were unhappy with the size of the planned payout and the company's proposal to use securities instead of cash to satisfy claims. They proposed the complete liquidation of Southmark. Junior debtholders and equity holders also opposed the original plan, arguing that they would not fare as well as senior debtholders. The new reorganization plan retains a controversial deal Southmark made with federal thrift regulators to retain control of San Jacinto. Under the new plan, the company's senior creditors will receive up to $75 million in cash, as well as secured notes and stock in the reorganized Southmark, the company said. The reorganization and future management of the company will be supervised by a new board of directors to be elected by the creditors. Holders of subordinated debt will receive stock in the reorganized company and other considerations. Senior and subordinated creditors will share in proceeds that may be received by Southmark from litigation resulting from the company's failure. Southmark's current common and preferred shareholders will receive a portion of common stock of the reorganized company. Southmark's bankruptcy filing, made in Atlanta and moved to Dallas, listed total assets of $1.046 billion, secured debt of $152.4 million, unsecured debt of $1.051 billion and other liabilities of $190.9 million. The unsecured creditors' committee said unsecured claims against Southmark were closer to $1.5 billion, The Dallas Morning News reported Saturday. Non-thrift assets the company has proposed selling include insurance, oil and nursing home companies, interest in casinos in Atlantic City and San Juan, Puerto Rico, and numerous real estate partnerships. They were acquired mainly through financing provided by high-risk, high-yield junk bonds sold by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Poling Says Japan Has Certain Advantages Over U.S. Automakers
DOC.TEXT: The new chairman of Ford Motor Co. says there is some truth to the perception that Japanese automakers turn out a better quality product than their U.S. counterparts. ``If you look at the Japanese, I think we're equal to some and not as good as the best,'' Harold ``Red'' Poling said in an interview published in Sunday's editions of The Detroit News. ``Our objective is to get there. That says you get the reality and you're going to get the perception.'' Poling, who took over as chairman last month, said he doesn't believe the Japanese have a technological edge over America's Big Three automakers, but he said there is a disparity in operational costs. ``Can we get plants in the United States to produce vehicles as inexpensively as the Japanese do? You bet. But that requires shutting down your plants and starting from scratch. We can't do that. ``We have a workforce, we have retirees, we're committed to pensions and we're committed to health care. And that gives us a serious noncompetitive disadvantage going in. We have to deal with that somehow.''
